DOC.HEAD: Eighth U.S. Company Bombed in Philippines
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded at a U.S. paint company in Manila early Monday, the eighth blast at an American company in a week, police said. They said the explosion caused no casualties but broke windows and damaged a concrete wall of the Fuller O'Brien factory in suburban Mandaluyong. Col. Ernesto Diokno said rebel soldiers may have been behind the bombing because C-4 plastic explosive, issued only to the military, was used. Seven U.S. companies have been bombed since Wednesday. Monday's bombing was the 34th in the capital since August, when the spate of explosions began. Government offices and companies owned by Chinese-Filipino business people were targeted in the last two months. Authorities said the bombings are meant to frighten foreign investors and destabilize the economy, undermining the government of President Corazon Aquino.

DOC.HEAD: Striking Temple Professor's Reject Contract Offer
With AM-State College Woes, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-7, `Patricia Bradley...', with four grafs to UPDATE with university reaction. Picks up 8th graf, `The strike...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto PX1
DOC.TEXT: Temple University's striking professors rejected a second contract offer Sunday night as the threat of canceling hundreds of classes for the entire semester loomed. Common Pleas Judge Samuel Lehrer planned to reopen a hearing Monday into the university's request that he force the professors back to work. The proposal, which union members said offered little new, was rejected by a vote of 372 to 62. If pickets are still marching Tuesday, 40 percent, or 1,900 of Temple's 4,700 classes, will be canceled for lack of a professor. University officials say there is no alternative because there won't be enough days to make up lost class time before the spring semester starts. Patricia Bradley, a journalism professor, said 445 union members and 107 non-dues-paying members attended Sunday night's meeting. Only dues-paying members were allowed to vote. She said the union leadership recommended rejection of the offer. The proposal offered 5 percent salary increases over four years - instead of previous two- and three-year offers - and retained a request that the professors contribute $260 a year toward health insurance costs. ``They think we'll just get tired and give up,'' Bradley said. ``It's a union-busting strike - I think that's generally accepted.'' Temple's chief negotiator Bob Harrington said he was very disappointed by the vote. He said the union broke agreements that the entire bargaining unit would vote on the proposal, not just dues-paying members, and that the union leadership would not recommend how to vote. The strike began Sept. 4 when the teachers rejected 5 percent increases over the next two years. The teachers, whose salary averages about $45,500, want 7 percent pay increases and do not want to pay more for health care. Temple, an independent university that receives substantial state support, went to court after the first rejection seeking a court order to force teachers be ordered to return to class. The number of faculty members on strike is unclear. University officials and the Temple Association of University Professionals, which represents 1,100 faculty members, refuse to offer any estimates. Judge Lehrer held two days of hearings and got both sides to agree to the vote on the new offer. Both sides would return to court Monday if the offer was rejected, he said. Meanwhile, some of the school's 30,000 students have blocked city streets daily and stood outside a courtroom chanting their protest of anything less than a fully operational university. Some were arrested for invading Liacouras' office. Time has already run out for some students missing one or more classes they need for a degree. ``The whole thing stinks,'' said James Cunningham, 20, a sophomore in radio, television and film who was one of more than 100 students who have withdrawn from school. The deadline for withdrawal from school with a full refund is Oct. 8. Some 23,000 students are missing at least one class in the fall semester and 6,000 have had no classes at all because of the walkout. ``They are yanking the carpet from under my feet,'' said Doug Miller, 27, a senior architecture student. If classes don't resume, he will not be taking enough credits to be classified as a full-time studnet and could lose at least part of his financial aid. Temple lawyer John Langel said that if the offer is rejected, all classes that aren't meeting by Tuesday will be canceled. ``This is not going to be an educational institution,'' said striking history professor Michael Harris. ``It's going to be a phony. Basically, this institution is folding.''

DOC.HEAD: German-American Friendship Shines in Once-Isolated Enclave
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: EDITOR'S NOTE: This report is one of a series on the German countdown to unification on Wednesday.

The tiny village of Steinstuecken, just beyond the southwestern city limits of West Berlin, is only a small footnote to the Cold War era. But it looms large as a monument to German-American friendship. That friendship was celebrated this weekend, as village residents turned out to say thanks and farewell to the American soldiers who were their lifeline to the West. After World War II, the community of 200 people became part of West Berlin, and fell under the American sector. But when the Berlin Wall went up, the village was cut off from the metropolis by a narrow strip of East German territory. Only one road link was open. Strict controls hampered residents on trips to Berlin. Villagers feared there would be a total blockade. That didn't happen - thanks to the Americans. U.S. military officials posted military police in the village. American helicopters made supply flights, providing the enclave with a vital link to the outside world. With the unification of East and West Germany a few days away, the villgers gathered Saturday to remember those difficult days. ``The Americans were our greatest security,'' said Gert Knecht, a villager in his 60s. He recalled the many friendships that developed. One American military policeman married a local girl, he said. Knecht likened Steinstuecken's plight to being able to walk around freely inside your home, but ``you couldn't go out in freedom.'' ``Our security came every week by helicopter,'' he said. Now the helicopter flights are commemorated by a monument in the village, with a design featuring chopper blades. The farewell gathering, held in a sunny poplar grove, didn't feature any brass bands or elaborate ceremonies. The people of Steinstuecken brought home-baked cakes and pies. Children clustered around Maj. Gen. Raymond E. Haddock, commandant of U.S. forces in West Berlin, as he handed out badges that said ``Deutsch-Amerikanische Freundschaft'' - German-American friendship. The regular helicopter flights ended in 1972 after East-West relations improved, but the U.S. Army aviation unit that flew the route kept up ties with Steinstuecken. A final flight was part of Saturday's ceremony. Villagers, joined by neighbors from the East, waved goodbye to the departing aircraft. ``We must protect this German-American friendship and widen it in the future,'' said the village mayor, Juergen Klemann. It is a theme that has been often expressed in the final days before the unification of East and West Germany at midnight Tuesday. Commentators warn that the present peaceful course of events and Germany's allegiance to the Western NATO alliance could change if the United States turned to isolationism and the Germans turned to anti-Americanism. The burghers of Steinstuecken believe they owe their Western standard of living - and their freedoms - to the years of American protection. But not all West Germans share their view of the U.S. military presence. In the early 1980s, hundreds of thousands of West Germans demonstrated against U.S. military policy in Europe, especially the stationing of medium-range nuclear missiles in Germany and other NATO-member nations. While the United States and West Germany enjoyed good relations during the administration of Chancellor Helmut Schmidt, who left office in 1982, Schmidt's Social Democratic Party showed increasing irritation with U.S. policies. It had long advocated a less militaristic posture of NATO. West Germans have become increasingly interested in cutting back U.S. troops in their country. There have even been calls for the shutdown of the sprawling Rhein-Main U.S. Air Force base outside Frankfurt in central West Germany, to make room for the growing financial metropolis. Some of these pressures have been removed - the medium-range nuclear missiles and the chemical weapons are gone - and U.S. and other Allied troops in Germany are to be reduced in response to improved relations with the Soviet Union. Will future generations of Germans remember the missile disputes and the ear-splitting low-level training flights of the U.S. Air Force? Or will they remember the 1948-49 Berlin Airlift and the special attention paid to Steinstuecken? Gen. Haddock, whose powers as a military governor of West Berlin end at midnight Tuesday, said in his farewell speech that ``we have an obligation to keep alive the memory'' of the airlift and the chapter of history written in Steinstuecken. ``For they indicate the points at which the history of Germany and the United States of America was a common one,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Uncertainty Pervades Election Outlook in House Races
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Elections for the nation's 435 House seats are likely to yield only slight shifts in power, but analysts caution that this year's voting could be among the most volatile and unpredictable in years. November's balloting will follow ``one of the strangest 18 months in recent political history,'' analyst Charles Cook says of a period that has seen upheavals in Eastern Europe, the Persian Gulf, domestic issues and the American economy. Few are willing to bet on where it all will lead, but most analysts and operatives are guessing that Democrats will pad their 258-to-176 majority by less than 10 seats. In normal times, that would be a face-saving outcome for Republicans. As the party in control of the White House, the GOP historically could expect to lose 15 or more House seats in an off-year election. Several factors would seem to favor the GOP this time around. President Bush enjoys near-record popularity ratings, his standing increased by his handling of the Middle East crisis. And polls show a general public disgust with Congress, which is controlled by the Democrats. But on the other side of the ledger, the economy - among the most powerful determinants of political fortune - is headed downward. And Republicans are being forced to defend more so-called ``open'' seats, where there is no incumbent seeking re-election, because 11 otherwise safe GOP House members are running for the Senate or state offices. The effect of the volatility has been to put most races into slow motion. Congress, which had planned to adjourn by Oct. 5 so members could go home and campaign, now is unlikely to get out of Washington until Oct. 20 or so. Issues that have taken on local importance, from abortion to taxes and the savings and loan crisis, have had to compete for air time and headlines with developments in Iraq and Kuwait. Political experts say the effect will be to compress the intense part of the election season into the final two weeks. For one in five House districts, that will make no difference. Seventy-six incumbent lawmakers - 42 Democrats and 34 Republicans - will coast to re-election without major party opposition. And, as has become common in House contests, few of their colleagues have much to worry about. Political analysts single out fewer than two dozen races where the incumbent is endangered. Topping that list are Reps. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., Charles Pashayan, R-Calif., and Denny Smith, R-Ore., all of whom are linked to the $500 billion scandal over the failure of the savings and loan industry. A handful of others are in trouble because of political or ethical problems: - Rep. Arlan Stangeland, R-Minn., got in hot water for charging taxpayers for hundreds of long-distance calls to a female former employee of a lobbying firm. - It was revealed that Rep. Roy Dyson, D-Md., who accepts large contributions from the defense industry in his capacity as an Armed Services Committee member, claimed conscientious objector status during the Vietnam War. - Rep. Stan Parris, R-Va., said during a debate with his Democratic opponent that he opposes affirmative action because ``it is worse to discriminate against majorities'' than against racial minorities. And always vulnerable are freshmen, many of whom won narrowly in 1988 and have yet to establish themselves firmly in their new seats: Ben Jones, D-Ga.; George Sangmeister, D-Ill.; Bill Sarpalius, D-Texas; Greg Laughlin, D-Texas; Peter Hoagland, D-Neb.; Jolene Unsoeld, D-Wash.; Craig James, R-Fla.; Ron Machtley, R-R.I.; and Peter Smith, R-Vt. Most of the action, and the attention of Democratic and Republican party operatives, focuses on the 2 open seats where there is no incumbent. Eleven are seats previously held by Democrats, and 18 were formerly GOP seats. One hotspot is Maine's First District, where Democrat Joseph Brennan is running to get back his old job as governor. Fighting for Brennan's House seat are Democratic state Sen. Tom Andrews and Republican David Emery, who is making a comeback bid. Also tough for Democrats to defend is the Cincinnati district of Thomas Luken, who is retiring. Luken's son, Mayor Charles Luken, is vying against Ken Blackwell, a former Cincinnati mayor and official of the Department of Housing and Urban Development. Blackwell is the GOP's best hope of electing a black Republican to a House seat in five decades. A slugfest has developed in the Texas, where Democratic Rep. Marvin Leath is retiring. State Sen. Chet Edwards, a Democrat, is running to replace him against Republican Hugh Shine, a state House member. Shine has been attacking Edwards for appearing at a fund-raiser for a gay and lesbian group in Houston last year. Democrats see their best hopes at picking open seats in Arkansas, where Democrat-turned-Republican Tommy Robinson left his seat to run for governor; and in Rhode Island, Hawaii, Iowa and Idaho, where Republican House members are running for Senate seats.

DOC.HEAD: Gantt Looks for `People Power' To Unseat Helms
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-House Rdp
DOC.TEXT: When Harvey Gantt exhorts people to get religion and ``show some signs,'' he doesn't mean they should start speaking in tongues. He's talking about a U.S. Senate race that only ``people power'' can win. People power brought down communism in Eastern Europe, and Gantt's task seems hardly less formidable. He's trying to dislodge Republican Jesse Helms, North Carolina's controversial and well-financed three-term senator. Be missionaries for me, Gantt tells black county employees, white mountainfolk and wine-and-cheese liberals across the state. Be truth squads for me. Get out the vote for me, he says, and ``we can demonstrate that people power is stronger than all the money in the world.'' Helms, an outspoken conservative with a national fund-raising network, has been pulling in campaign contributions at a record-breaking pace. And while his views and style alienate many voters, he has a devoted following and a hard-hitting campaign style that has crushed all of his previous opponents, including a sitting governor. But challenges are a way of life for Gantt, a soft-spoken architect. He was the first black student at Clemson University, the first black mayor of Charlotte, the national Democratic Party's first black Senate nominee in this century. A victory in November would make him the first black southern senator since Reconstruction. Polls show a dead-even race with few voters undecided. But Gantt radiated calm and confidence on a recent campaign journey that took him from depressed rural pockets in North Carolina's northeast corner to wealthy coastal villages on the Outer Banks. ``We really are going to bring Jesse Helms home,'' he told a racially balanced crowd at a ``pig-picking'' barbecue on the sweeping lawn of a riverfront home. Neither Helms' multimillion-dollar campaign warchest nor his aura of invincibility fazes Gantt. ``I've never seen him as being a great power. I've always seen him as a beneficiary of good luck,'' he says. Gantt, 47, carries a traditional Democratic message of populism and government compassion, enlivened with tales of his humble origins and gentle digs at Helms. Though some fans wear Gantt-for-Senate buttons that say ``Making History,'' Gantt does not present himself as a pioneering standard-bearer for blacks. He'd rather be viewed as the unifying, forward-looking alternative to a man he says has few allies and pushes divisive priorities that are irrelevant to most North Carolinians. ``It's all right to get somebody who'll stand up for what he or she believes in,'' Gantt tells supporters, repeating the rationale many voters give for choosing Helms. ``But you also ought to get somebody who'll stand up for you.'' Helms' prickly personality is at least part of the reason North Carolina gets a poor return on the tax dollars it sends to Washington, Gantt told a group of courthouse employees. ``I've got to think it has to do with the fact that he's kind of ornery. He doesn't get along with anybody,'' Gantt said mildly as the air filled with knowing chuckles. Gantt also accuses Helms of ``thumbing his nose'' at the state's voters by refusing to debate, publicize his schedule or answer questions. If the two candidates stood side by side and talked about their visions, Gantt told an affluent Nags Head gathering, ``I could win every time. I'm convinced of that.'' He added, to laughter, ``I think he's kind of convinced of that, too.'' Gantt makes no bones about his vision - a government that helps ensure jobs, health care, education and a clean environment for its citizens. ``If liberal means caring about people, then I'm a liberal,'' he told those gathered on the banks of the Pasquotank River for the pig-picking. ``I just want us to return to our party and its heritage and its great leaders.'' It was an apt message for that area, which went for Helms in 1984 despite an overwhelming Democratic edge in voter registration. Gantt's unabashed liberalism ultimately may not prove any more popular among moderates than Helms' extreme, often combative conservativism. But he has been attracting overflow crowds and devoted converts, from the mountains to the shore. Gwen Cruickshanks, the Currituck County Democratic chairwoman, said out-of-staters at a national businesswomen's conference in Charlotte bombarded her with unsolicited checks after Gantt spoke. ``That's the galvanizing effect this man has,'' she said. Gantt also is galvanizing blacks. ``G-A-N-T-T, it really sounds good to me, Harvey, Harvey,'' hundreds of black students chanted at a rally at Elizabeth City State College. Gantt, who designed three buildings at the college, was mobbed, embraced, begged for autographs. ``I'm going to be there for you,'' promised the would-be senator. ``My door is going to be open for you.'' But blacks account for only 20 percent of North Carolina's voting-age population. And while he won two mayoral terms in 75-percent-white Charlotte, Gantt's race could handicap him in a contest where every last vote will count. ``I meet lots of people who say `I've never voted for a black man and I'm not going to now,''' said Gail Singh, a white Gantt supporter who runs a video business on the Outer Banks. ``You can't say there's no race factor in northeastern North Carolina.'' Gantt does not concede a ``race factor,'' just as he will not concede that Helms' financial advantage translates into a competitive edge. Helms had raised $6 million as of June 30, compared to Gantt's $853,000. The Democrat said his campaign is ``on track'' toward a goal of raising $5 million to $7 million. He called that ``more than sufficient to maintain a reasonable amount of television. We don't run as many commercials as Jesse Helms. We just buy smarter.'' Helms is making few appearances and relying almost entirely on TV ads, including scathing attacks on Gantt's support for abortion rights and reductions in defense spending. Gantt says he watches them and is amused. ``I end up laughing,'' he said. ``Then I realize I've got to be serious - some people believe this.'' Gantt is running spots that attack Helms' education record, his anti-abortion position and what he considers the senator's misplaced priorities, such as his crusade against federal funding for obscene art. But Gantt also has warm and fuzzy ads in which he talks about his background and beliefs, supplementing his personal efforts to introduce himself to voters around the state. He tells his life story often, and nowhere was the tale more poignant than at the Perquimans County Courthouse, built in the slave days of 1825. Gantt, a descendant of slaves, stood at the front of a small, colonial-style courtroom that looks like a setting for the Continental Congress. ``I come from a working-class family. My father had an eighth-grade education,'' he began. He traced his father's life: two and three jobs at a time, the government loan that allowed him to move the family from public housing to their own home, the government restoring his dignity with civil rights laws, the government helping him put five children through college. Of his own fortunes, and the threshold on which he now stands, Gantt said nothing then. But later, at a Nags Head fern bar crowded with the well-heeled, he wore an exuberant grin as he declared: ``Only in America.''

DOC.HEAD: Court To Decide on Medicating Prisoner To Allow Execution
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Michael Owen Perry's medicine could restore his sanity, but it has one enormous side effect: It could speed his death. Perry is a prisoner on Death Row, and his fate will be argued Tuesday before the U.S. Supreme Court. The state of Louisiana wants to force him to take psychiatric medication; if he is legally sane, he can be executed. Perry's lawyers argue that forcible medicating would be a cruel and unusual punishment that ignores Perry's rights to avoid unwanted medication. The American Medical Association and the American Psychiatric Association say treating Perry to aid in his execution would turn the healing art on its head. Perry's sentence should be commuted to life in prison, they suggest. ``We're saying the cost here, which is really a fundamental realignment of the role of medicine, is a very high cost, and the state's interest in the difference between capital punishment and life imprisonment without parole doesn't justify that cost,'' said attorney Joel Klein. The state says giving him the drug is simply a necessary step for carrying out a death sentence, a justifiable limitation on a condemned man's liberties much like strapping him into the electric chair. Besides, the state is required to provide medical care, and the medicine is good for him, Louisiana says. Perry, 35, suffers from schizoaffective disorder, causing him delusions, hallucinations and disordered thinking. He was sentenced in 1985 for shooting his parents and three other family members to death. Louisiana's supreme court affirmed the conviction and the sentence but suggested a review of Perry's mental competence to be executed. There is a tradition in Anglo-American law that people should not be executed while insane. This doctrine, which dates back to medieval times, was adopted by the U.S. Supreme Court in a 1986 decision. ``Insanity'' is a legal term, not a medical one. In this case it refers to mental illness so severe that the prisoner is not aware of the impending punishment and why he is to suffer it. The Louisiana court ruled Perry was sane, but only while on medication. It also ordered that Perry be medicated even over his objection. After the state supreme court refused to hear a challenge to that decision, Perry's lawyers appealed to the federal high court. Lawyers for both sides declined to be interviewed on the record, but their Supreme Court briefs lay out their arguments in detail. Lawyers for Louisiana say the death sentence wiped out any legal power Perry would have to refuse the medication. Forced medication would not be a ``cruel and unusual'' punishment because Perry would benefit medically from it, the state says. ``Common sense dictates that the State does not violate the Eighth Amendment by doing something good for a prisoner.'' In fact, Louisiana is required to medicate Perry because the Supreme Court has declared that deliberately ignoring a prisoner's serious medical need itself constitues cruel and unusual punishment, the brief says. Perry's attorneys say the forced medication would be unconstitutional punishment rather than treatment. The court order gives no consideration to Perry's medical needs nor physician judgment, they say. The order also ignores the ``very real'' prospect of serious side effects, raising the prospect of taking a ``drooling, incontinent and tremulus'' man to the execution chamber, they wrote. In any case, Perry's lawyers say, Perry's response to medication is sporadic and unpredictable, making it impossible to say whether he would be competent on the day of his execution. ``With this instability and unpredictability, how is Michael's execution to be carried out?'' the lawyers asked. ``Can the state wait until a `good day' and execute Michael? Can Michael be executed if his `good days' outnumber his `bad days' by some amount? What amount? And what happens if the date set in the death warrant is a `bad day?' '' The AMA and psychiatric association, meanwhile, say the death sentence does not outweigh Perry's interest in avoiding unwanted medication, an interest especially great ``when the injection sets the prisoner directly on the road to execution.'' Involuntary medication was not part of Perry's sentence, nor is it generally authorized by confinement, the associations argue. Prior court decision support the idea that involuntary medical treatment is not permitted if it runs against a person's medical interests and is not necessary to treat a condition that may harm other people, they say. As for the argument that the medication would help Perry, any benefit ``would be both fleeting and purchased at the cost of his life,'' the associations said in a brief. Outside observers are split on their reaction to the case. Dr. Gary Glass, an associate psychiatry professor at Temple University and lecturer in law at Villanova University, said he personally hopes that the court would not allow execution of a person who is incompetent when not treated. But his ``utilitarian, practical'' answer is that nobody should be allowed to make a competent decision to avoid execution by becoming legally incompetent, he said. If a death sentence is imposed, ``people ought not to be able to use their mental health and illness to manipulate that decision,'' he said. Arthur Caplan, director of the Center for Biomedical Ethics at the University of Minnesota, calls it ``fundamentally wrong for any health care professional to give anybody psychiatric medication against their will for a non-therapeutic purpose.'' If authorities are intent on executing a man while he is sane in such cases, they should specify medication as part of the sentence and not pretend it is medical treatment, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Islamics in Algeria Dominate Arab Country's Rush to Democracy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: This capital now boils with political activity as Algeria undertakes an Arab-style transition toward democracy. One question dominates: will free elections in this North African country replace a Marxist-style dictatorship with an Islamic one? The potent brew of politics and religion bubbles to life each evening in the Casbah, where bearded young men sip mint tea and dissect democracy and the Koran in a capital long derided as ``Moscow on the Med.'' ``Vive FIS'' (``Long Live The Islamic Salvation Front'') reads the graffiti on the Ketchaoua mosque, a bastion of Algeria's most potent political movement. ``This is a Moslem country,'' said Ali Hamidouche, 32. ``It's only natural that people would want a Moslem government.'' The 28 political parties and lively free press born since constitutional reforms in 1989 contrast sharply with an Arab world ruled by monarchs, dictators and one-party states. But vows by Islaic councils elected last June to impose Koranic law fuel fears that the democratic experiment may be short. ``If the FIS wins, we're dead,'' a leading women's rights activist said. The Islamic Salvation Front took control of more than half the country's municipal and regional councils June 12 in Algeria's first free elections since independence from France in 1962. The verdict repudiated the ruling National Liberation Front (FLN) and its 28-year monopoly on power. But local councils hold little power. The fundamentalists cannot effect changes while the FLN holds all seats in the National Assembly. Their complaints forced President Chadli Bendjedid to move legislative elections ahead a year to next spring. ``No matter who wins, the first success of these elections will be stability and legitimacy for the National Assembly,'' FIS leader Abassi Madani said in a recent newspaper interview. The 59-year-old philosophy professor presents the moderate face of a movement encompassing classical scholars and pro-Iranian radicals. His alter ego is Ali Belhadj, 31, whose fiery speeches attract thousands. He blames ``infidels'' - France chief among them - for Algeria's woes. For the young men outside the Ketchaoua mosque, the FIS heralds an end to the Soviet-inspired system the National Liberation Front imposed on Algeria, one of the continent's largest countries and situated on the Mediterranean. The fundamentalists' message is clear: the old regime was corrupt. It brought poverty and unemployment. An Islamic regime will stop corruption and, thereby, social problems. The FIS vows to end to secular practices that let men and women mingle at school and work. ``For us, secularism means liberty from God,'' Hamidouche said with a grimace. Ranged against the fundamentalists are dozens of political groupings, but only a handful with significant support. The FLN remains the best organized. Thousands of its adherents run the public sector to which most Algerians owe their livelihood. But the FLN managed only to win a quarter of the June vote. ``They'll be lucky to keep 25 percent next time,'' a Western diplomat said. ``People are fed up, and they've thrown up no young, charismatic leader.'' The oppostion includes the liberal Rally for Culture and Democracy, the centrist Front for Socialist Forces and the populist Movement for Democracy in Algeria. The Rally received a boost when the other two parties boycotted the June voting, claiming the FLN would rig the results. Their leaders are heroes of the war for independence - Berber chief Hocine Ait Ahmed and Algeria's first president, Ahmed Ben Bella. Ben Bella, 73, is the man Algerians are watching. He hopes to weld a ``democratic consensus'' to lead the country out of its economic ills. Ben Bella's stature is unrivaled by any living Algerian. He planned the 1954 uprising against France and ruled three years after independence until toppled in a military coup. On Thursday, Sept. 27, he returned to Algiers from exile in Geneva, telling his countrymen, ``I don't come back to settle scores. I come back to help my country build itself.'' Half of Ben Bella's life has been spent in exile or prison. ``They never broke him,'' said Hocine Guermouche, spokesman for the Movement for Democracy in Algeria. ``You've seen Mandela. He spent 27 years in prison and never lost his spirit. Ben Bella has done more ... he won the war.'' But he also gave Algeria ills it is only now shaking off: secret police, a single-party system, a Marxist economy. Whoever wins next year's elections will struggle to revive the sagging economy. In October 1988, thousand of Algerians rioted over living standards that plummeted along with prices for the country's chief export, oil. Scores of people, including many fundamentalists, died when the army crushed the uprising. The deaths robbed the FLN of popular legitimacy. Bendjedid, whose term expires in 1993, distanced the government from the FLN and drafted last year's constitutional reforms. He appointed technocrats to impose market economics. No party seems likely to meddle with the privatization program. But the pace of economic change remains slow. Unemployment officially stands at 25 percent. Families of 12 often live in two-room apartments. The government estimates 800,000 new dwellings are needed. Long lines form at shops often empty of basic foodstuffs. Jobless young men survive by hawking black-market cigarettes. Strikes proliferate. As the meuzzin at Ketchaoua mosque called the faithful to prayer, one young man said lots of political parties are fine, as long as they adhere to Islam. ``If the people vote for the FIS, fine. If they vote for ... some other party and they win, that's good, too,'' said Boumari Nacer Edde, a Casbah candy seller. ``The important thing is that there's democracy. We want democracy.''

DOC.HEAD: Money, Indifference Block Path to Islamic Morality
With PM-Algeria-Fundamentalists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: The burst of repression expected to follow this summer's election victory by Islamic fundamentalists hasn't materialized. Take the case of Tipasa. This Mediterranean resort welcomes tens of thousands of European and Algerian tourists a year to pristine beaches and extensive Roman ruins. Not long after the 15,000 residents elected a council dominated by the Islamic Salvation Front (FIS), posters went up announcing a ban against shorts. The news quickly reaching Europe was portrayed as evidence the fundamentalists knew no limits in imposing strict morality. How could shorts be banned in a beach town? The impression of fire-breathing fundamentalists imposing a draconian crackdown killed the season. ``June and July were just dead - there were almost no Europeans,'' Ahmed Mansour remarked on the empty terrace of his restaurant. But town administrator Mohammed Essamelli says the reality of the ban was more complicated. ``First, this law's been here since 1965,'' said Essamelli. ``All the new council did was say they intended to enforce it.'' Second, the law does not affect Tipasa's beaches, where men and women in Western swimwear outnumber those in long robes 20 to one. It covers only the town center and was modeled on similar rules on the French Riviera 25 years ago, Essamelli said. The law permits shorts in town if they reach the top of the knee for men or the bottom of the knee for women. Essamelli finds this reasonable. Mansour notes that no police officer has bothered to enforce the ordinance and says the fundamentalists don't want to bite the economic hand that feeds the electorate. ``Nobody has come here asking us to stop selling alcohol,'' he said. ``They may be for Islam, but they know this country needs other things, too.'' The Tipasa case finds echoes elsewhere. Stories proliferate of official crackdowns on ice cream and alcohol. Most turn out to be exaggerated. Many of the reports originate with the official APS news agency, an organ of the ruling National Liberation Front. The fundamentalists thrashed the party in the elections. The fundamentalists certainly hope to change Algerian society. Councils have moved to segregate boys and girls at school. The movement debates whether women should work. But in the absence of holding national power - legislative elections are planned next spring - the changes are mostly limited to cosmetics. In Oran, Algeria's second city, humor made a difference. Fundamentalist councilors there denounced a festival of the popular rai music, which celebrates youthful revolt. They said one devoted to Islamic music would be better. A rai singer responded with a number featuring a compromise refrain: ``I voted for the FIS, I voted for the FIS.''

DOC.HEAD: State Colleges Feeling The Pinch of Tightening Finances
DOC.TEXT: With state governments increasingly strapped for revenue, many public universities are facing their worst money crunch in years this fall. Campuses in at least 15 states - mostly on the East Coast and Midwest where state budgets are tightest - are operating on bare-bones budgets that have led to program cuts, fewer and more crowded classes, and faculty cutbacks. The average tuition increase at state colleges was 7 percent this fall, according to a College Board survey. But in a few states, tuition already is heading up in double digits. And experts fear new, more widespread increases as early as midterm if local economies worsen. ``We're in a situation that's deteriorating very rapidly,'' said Richard Novak, director of state education policy and finance of the American Association of State Colleges and Universities. ``What's happening in Northeastern and Midwestern states is spreading very rapidly down the coast. They are facing sharp cuts that will have untold impact on those institutions.'' An Associated Press survey found: - Student fees are up 10 percent and numerous cuts are affecting California State University's 20 campuses after state higher education appropriations rose just 2.6 percent to $1.69 billion. At San Francisco State, 250 fall classes were canceled. The San Diego campus cut library hours and the number of people who shelve books. Thirty faculty positions will go unfilled at the San Luis Obispo campus. - The president of the University of Massachusetts has warned he may have to fire teachers and cancel a week of classes following state higher education cuts of $27 million during the last two years, including a $4.2 million cut announced by Gov. Michael S. Dukakis the day classes opened. - Tuition at New Jersey's nine state colleges is up between 9.6 percent and 19.4 percent. - Rhode Island's three major state schools have raised their rates about 9 percent after receiving $2.2 million less than they did last year because of state budget problems. - The Florida Board of Regents has told the state's nine universities to come up with $49 million in cuts to help make up a $521 million state shortfall. Among the possibilities: eliminating the first summer school term in 1991. - The City University of New York, faced with $42 million in budget cuts, is tightening enrollment procedures, canceling 2,000 classes, dropping 670 adjunct teachers and cutting library hours. - After three years of sharp funding increases, Maryland Gov. William Donald Schaefer has asked that higher education funds be cut $41 million during the current fiscal year because of a $150 million shortfall in state revenue. - Students staged a ``Save UNC'' rally this fall at the University of North Carolina to protest cuts that have led to fewer classes and students sitting on the floor in others. In several states, including Ohio, Massachusetts and Oklahoma, declining enrollment is further clouding the financial outlook at state campuses. The picture isn't gloomy everywhere. Public campuses in Iowa, Louisiana, Utah, Idaho, Texas, New Mexico and Arizona are among those enjoying increased state appropriations and relatively modest tuition increases. Appropriations at the University of Iowa are up 9.6 percent; tuition is up just 3 percent. With state funding in Louisiana up more than 11 percent, tuition at Southern University didn't increase at all this fall. State appropriations to higher education increased an average of 7 percent during the last two years, according to a study by the National Association of State Universities and Land-Grant Colleges. Novak projects gains will be only half that in 1990-91, ``well below inflation and well below need.'' He and other also foresee a spread of sharp tuition increases. In Nebraska, campus officials are quaking over a proposed amendment limiting state spending. The amendment on the Nov. 6 ballot would hold annual budget increases to 2 percent. ``We don't have a crisis right now, but the big issue is the 2 percent thing,'' said Rich Bringelson, executive officer of the Nebraska State College System. In North Carolina, a $336 million budget shortfall has meant appropriations to state campuses were cut by 5 percent - the third straight year the schools have received less than they requested. It's reached the point where students prefer a tuition increase to further program cuts. ``All of this is revolutionary talk, but I think there is sentiment for supporting a tuition increase if it is reverted back to the universities,'' said William Hildebolt, student body president at UNC-Chapel Hill.

DOC.HEAD: Charlie Brown And The Gang Turn 40!
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY17
DOC.TEXT: Good grief: The Peanuts gang is turning 40. The images are embedded in American popular culture: Charlie Brown trying to kick a football, Snoopy gunning for the Red Baron and Lucy dispensing psychiatric advice, a nickel's worth at a time. Now it's time to celebrate. In honor of the 40th anniversary of the comic strip ``Peanuts,'' there's a jazz concert at Carnegie Hall, a birthday party at the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County and a special exhibit at the Smithsonian Institution. On Oct. 2, 1950, ``Peanuts'' made its debut in seven newspapers, and good ol' Charlie Brown and his beguiling beagle were on their way to becoming an international phenomenon. Today the strip runs in 2,300 newspapers and reaches more than 200 million readers a day in 68 countries. The Peanuts gang speaks Chinese, even Serbo-Croatian. There's been a hit musical, ``You're a Good Man, Charlie Brown,'' a series of TV specials and a book on the philosophical and religious implications of the strip, ``The Gospel According to Peanuts.'' In September, cartoonist Charles M. Schulz was one of Forbes magazine's top 10 richest entertainers, with earnings for 1989 and 1990 estimated at $54 million. Unlike many cartoonists, the 67-year-old Schulz still draws every comic strip himself. ``Why do musicians compose symphonies and poets write poems?'' he asked. ``They do it because life wouldn't have any meaning for them if they didn't. ``That's why I draw cartoons. It's my life.'' The cartoonist was born in St. Paul, Minn. He studied art in high school, after he saw a ``Do you like to draw?'' ad. Schulz later did lettering for a church comic book, taught art and sold cartoons to the Saturday Evening Post. His cartoon feature ``Li'l Folks,'' the forerunner of Peanuts, was developed for the St. Paul Pioneer Press in 1947. The strip was sold to a syndicate in 1950, and the name changed to ``Peanuts.'' Charlie, the round-headed boy in the sawtooth shirt, was named after a friend at art school and is the cartoonist's alter ego. Snoopy was inspired by a dog he had as a child. The little red-haired girl - Charlie's unrequited love who is never shown in the strip - was based on a girlfriend who rejected Schulz's proposal of marriage. Through the years, for the millions of readers, Charlie and his gang have been like family. Followers know that Snoopy - in his World War I flying ace incarnation - flies a Sopwith Camel. They know Linus needs his security blanket and awaits the Great Pumpkin every Halloween. They know Schroeder plays Beethoven on his tiny piano. The 40th birthday festivities kicked off at the Super Bowl in New Orleans in January with a halftime show featuring the Peanuts characters. On Monday, the Natural History Museum of Los Angeles County will salute Charlie, Snoopy, Linus, Schroeder, Peppermint Patty, Sally, Lucy - and Schulz - with an exhibit that premiered at the Louvre in January. There will be original artwork by Schulz, excerpts from the more than 40 Peanuts television shows and Snoopy mementos that were carried aboard NASA's Apollo 10 mission. New York City will toast Schulz and his characters Oct. 24 with a jazz concert at Carnegie Hall, featuring saxophonist Grover Washington Jr. and bassist Ron Carter. The Peanuts TV special have been noted for their original jazz scores. Opening Oct. 30 at the Smithsonian is ``This is Your Childhood, Charlie Brown - Children in American Culture, 1945-1970,'' an exhibit that looks at how Schulz's comic strips reflected childhood and American culture after World War II. There will also be a ``Snoopy: The Universal Dog'' exhibit at the Dog Museum in St. Louis, starting Nov. 11. A Peanuts exhibit is now on display at the Museum of Cartoon Art in San Francisco.

DOC.HEAD: First Checks Due World War II Japanese-American Internees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Monday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto SE1 sent Sept. 30.
DOC.TEXT: Frank Yatsu never thought he'd live to see his government apologize for imprisoning him in World War II. But a check carrying that message should arrive in a few days, just before he turns 107. ``That's pretty good, I think,'' Yatsu said. ``The American government treated us in a Christian way and it's pretty good.'' The government soon will start sending $20,000 checks to each of the surviving Japanese-Americans sent to internment camps during the war. The last of the checks will be mailed in the federal government's fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, 1992. It was unclear exactly when the checks would go out, but officials said last week they hoped to begin issuing them in early October if White House and congressional budget negotiators reached agreement on a budget. That agreement was reached Sunday and Congress approved a resolution to continue funding for federal agencies, averting furloughs and cuts that could have delayed issuing the checks. Mary Grace Jennings, a spokeswoman for the federal Office of Redress Administration, said last week that officials hoped to have the first checks out by Oct. 9. The office also has proposed that the checks be accompanied by a letter of apology signed by President Bush and was working with the White House toward that, she said. For many, the payments will do much to erase the shame of internment and the decades of bitterness that followed, said Cressey Nakagawa, president of the Japanese American Citizens League, which led the fight for the reparations. ``I think, in many instances, people will even frame the letter,'' Nakagawa said from his San Francisco office. ``The checks will be consequential, but most meaningful will be the apology.'' The government rounded up Japanese-Americans in 1942 after war roke out with Japan, distrusting their loyalty. German-Americans did not receive such treatment. About 120,000 people were forced to abandon nearly all their possessions and were confined at 10 camps, most in remote inland areas of the West, and at scattered hospitals and sanitariums. Among them was Robert Matsui, who was 6 months old when he, his sister and parents were sent to a camp, despite all having been born and raised in Sacramento, Calif. They spent four years as internees. Matsui, now a Democratic congressman from California, sponsored the repayment bill, with Rep. Norman Mineta, D-Calif., and Sens. Daniel Inouye and Spark Matsunaga, both D-Hawaii. Passage of the measure ``was something of a catharsis'' for many Japanese-Americans, Matsui said. ``It was an issue of shame for the longest time,'' he said. ``The shame of having been accused by your own government of potentially being a spy. The worst thing that could happen to a citizen is being accused of being disloyal to your neighbor.'' It took years to square the experience in his own mind, Matsui said. ``I was not able to deal with this issue for the longest time, until about 1984 and 1985, when it really hit me that it really wasn't my fault that we were in this camp, it was the government's fault,'' he said. The tax-free checks will be distributed according to age, with Yatsu and 84 other centenarians getting them first. Yatsu, whose birthday is Oct. 13, isn't the oldest. First in line are a woman in Phoenix and a man in Santa Monica, Calif., both 107, said Bob Bratt, administrator of the Redress Administration. Yatsu and Harry Nakagawa, 100, are among five former internees cared for by Seattle Keiro, a Japanese community nursing home, who have lived more than a century. Both men remember the war years well. Nakagawa, who immigrated to Seattle in 1905, had a successful grocery with his son when he and his family were sent to a camp in Minidoka, Idaho. He said his landlady let him keep his possessions in the store's basement, but she died before his return and ``I lost everything.'' He later worked in a hotel and private club in Seattle. Yatsu, a teacher who immigrated to California in 1906, spent the war at an Arizona camp. Afterward, he made his way to Seattle where he worked for a window company. Yatsu said he would use his money to go live with a daughter in San Diego. Nakagawa said he would donate some to the Buddhist and Baptist churches. Both, speaking in a mix of English and Japanese translated by a Seattle Keiro worker, said they were amazed and pleased the government acknowledged its wrong. ``It's a good thing. . . . Other American people think we were enemy people and they no like,'' Yatsu said. The payments were authorized by the Civil Liberties Act of 1988, but $1.25 billion for the program wasn't allocated by Congress until last October. Congress approved $500 million for 25,000 payments in fiscal 1990, the same amount the following year and the remainder beginning in October 1992. That was based on estimates that about 65,000 internees were alive in 1988, but Bratt said his office had found about 70,000, nearly three-quarters of whom live in California.

DOC.HEAD: Banning of Pro-Democracy Magazine Criticized
DOC.TEXT: Diplomats and watchdog groups Saturday expressed dismay at the government's decision to ban a respected magazine that advocated multiparty politics and attacked official corruption. The Nairobi Law Monthly was the fourth publication banned by the government of President Daniel arap Moi in the past two years. ``The publication has been an important forum for legal and social commentary,'' said a spokesman at the U.S. Embassy in Nairobi. ``We hope the banning would be reconsidered.'' The New York-based Committee to Protect Journalists called the closing of the 3-year-old monthly ``the latest blow in a campaign of intimidation and harassment aimed at this publication.'' ``Its staff has been maligned, persecuted and jailed,'' the group said in a statement to Moi, who has ruled Kenya for 12 years. Attorney General Matthew Muli signed the order Friday banning the magazine, whose editor, Gitobu Imanyara, was detained for three weeks in July and charged with sedition in July. ``The Nairobi Law Monthly is one of thw few remaining press critics of Kenya's drift toward dictatorship,'' said a statement from New York-based Africa Watch, a human rights monitoring group. The ban came two days after Moi threatened to crack down on those calling for multiple political parties. A 1982 law allows only Moi's Kenya African National Union party in the East African nation of 23 million people. This week, Moi twice accused the Anglican Church of destabilizing the country. Nine bishops denied the charges in a statement Friday. The church and other critics have repeatedly decried alleged corruption, election-rigging and abuses in the judiciary. The government said security forces killed 20 people in four days or riots that followed the arrests of editor Imanyara, 36, and six other people. Africa Watch claimed more than 100 people were killed in the fighting. In the current issue of the Law Monthly, Imanyara called for political pluralism. He also wrote in an editorial urging the current Parliament be dissolved and new elections held, and that Kenya's presidents should be impeached if they violate the constitution. The September issue of the magazine sold more than 10,000 copies in a few hours in Nairobi, Africa Watch said.

DOC.HEAD: Site of Hostage Horror Reopens for Business
DOC.TEXT: A hotel bar where a gunman described as a schizophrenic killed a man and kept patrons hostage during a night of humiliation and terror reopened Saturday. Henry's Publick House & Grille served a few dozen customers after it reopened to a few gawkers, off-duty servers and some hotel guests. Bullet holes were still visible from Thursday's siege in which Iranian-born Mehrdad Dashti, 30, killed one young man and wounded seven others before he died in a hail of police gunfire. Manager Doug Moore, one of 33 people held hostage, said he returned to work because, ``I haven't been able to cry. I haven't been able to feel anything.'' The seven-hour siege, punctuated by Dashti's sporadic gunfire, ended when police failed to talk him into surrenduring and officers stormed the bar in the Durant Hotel. Dashti was described as a paranoid schizophrenic on an Alameda County mental health form. Police called him deranged.

DOC.HEAD: Chemical Plant Burns Near Houston
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tubilor cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: A fire raced through a chemical plant Saturday, injuring two firefighters and forcing the evacuation of local residents. The four-alarm blaze at the Tubilor Protectors of America plant was still burning late Saturday, firefighters said. Montgomery County sheriff's officers ordered a one-mile area around the plant to be evacuated, and extended the order to two miles on the northwest side, which was downwind. ``The whole building is burning,'' said sheriff's spokeswoman Debbie Yancy. The cause of the fire was not immediately determined. The plant, which processed several chemicals including the flammable gas methyl chloride, is about 25 miles northwest of Houston.

DOC.HEAD: No Damage Reported in 3.9 Quake
DOC.TEXT: CHALLIS, Idaho - A minor earthquake rattled dishes and left some people's nerves shaken Saturday in east-central Idaho. The quake, measuring 3.9 on the Richter scale, occurred at 7:08 p.m. and was centered about 10 miles southwest of Challis, said John Minsch, a geophysicist with the National Earthquake Information Center in Golden, Colo. He said a 3.9 earthquake is minor and unlikely to cause damage. ``Most people said it scared them and shook them up a little bit,'' said Mark Booker of radio station KSRA in Salmon, 58 miles north of Challis. Saturday's temblor occurred on the same fault line as a 7.3 quake that killed two children in Challis and caused $4 million damage in October 1983.

DOC.HEAD: 11th-Hour Budget Still Short of Agreement
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New throughout to reflect end of session, settlement of capital gains and Social Security
DOC.TEXT: Top congressional and Bush administration leaders, trying to stave off a chaotic shrinking of government services, ended more than 12 hours of negotiations early Sunday still without a final plan to reduce the federal deficit. All indications pointed to a final agreement. Sources said negotiators disposed of two of the toughest issues - capital gains tax cuts and higher taxes on Social Security recipients - by removing them from the package. Negotiations will resume at midday Sunday - 12 hours before deep cuts in many federal programs are due to take effect. Any tampering with Social Security a month before elections was just too unpalatable to most Democrats and many Republicans, congressional aides said. Apparently the biggest remaining obstacle to a final agreement was determining how to enforce the proposed deficit reductions in future years - that is, how to keep a new Congress in 1994, for example, from reneging on the spending cuts. Aides said some who have been pushing hardest for a cut in the capital gains tax had made clear they would rather postpone the issue until next year rather than accept any of several watered-down substitutes. ``There doesn't seem to be much life left in the issue this year,'' one Republican aide said of the capital gains cut, which has been a prime goal of President Bush since his 1988 election campaign. An official traveling with the president in New York said he could not confirm reports that the White House had dropped its insistence on a cut in the capital gains tax rate. But the official, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the negotiators were discussing ``all sorts of alternatives,'' including indexing to protect people from being taxed on gains that simply reflect inflation. ``It all depends on what they get for it,'' he said. A capital gains cut apparently fell victim to a Democratic effort to portray the reduction as a windfall for the rich. About 80 percent of the benefit of a tax cut on capital gains, which are investment profits, would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. Negotiators were optimistic they would be able to agree on a plan of targeted spending cuts and tax increases that would bring the largest deficit reductions in history: $50 billion in the budget year that begins Monday and another $450 billion over the following five years. ``It may take until early tomorrow morning,'' House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., told reporters as the Saturday talks began. ``I'm getting quite optimistic about it.'' Failure could trigger $85 billion in arbitrary cuts in many federal programs and forced furloughs of 1 million or more workers beginning Monday morning. The problem is made worse by the fact that Congress has yet to pass any of the 13 annual appropriation bills that pay for government programs in the new year. The House and Senate scheduled Sunday sessions in anticipation that their leaders would reach agreement on a deficit-reduction plan. If all goes according to schedule, the two chambers would approve stopgap legislation extending government spending authority temporarily and President Bush would sign it Sunday night. That would give lawmakers a few days to write a bill cutting spending and raising taxes to produce the deficit reduction. As negotiators convened on Saturday, aides gave conflicting reports on the status of the capital gains cut, which has been the most contentious issue in the more than four months of bargaining. ``I would not want to preclude it at this time,'' Foley said Saturday when asked if the capital gains proposal was still an option. He said the whole question of growth incentives and tax fairness - whether the rich should pay more - was still open. He and Senate Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas said negotiators were considering alternative ways of stimulating investment. Aides said those options include a limited deduction for long-held investments in smaller companies. By the time the session ended, however, the touchy capital gains issue had been put aside. That left another hot issue: whether Social Security beneficiaries should be required to shoulder a bigger portion of the cost of deficit reduction. In the end, the negotiators apparently said no. Democrats had proposed to raise from 50 percent to 85 percent the taxable portion of Social Security benefits received by those with higher incomes. Republicans favor a two- or three-month delay in the cost-of-living increase in Social Security benefits that is due to take effect next January. Leaders in both parties say either solution is likely to undermine support for the deficit-reduction package from lawmakers who remember the flood of mail from retirees last year that forced repeal of a catastrophic illness health plan for seniors and the tax increases that paid for it. The negotiators agreed earlier on large parts of the $500 billion package. It includes increases in taxes on beer, wine, liquor and gasoline; a new ``luxury'' tax on high-priced cars, jewels and electronic equipment; a slight tax on all forms of energy; $120 billion of cuts in domestic spending, and a $170 billion reduction in the military budget.

DOC.HEAD: Plane Crashes Into Lake; At Least Six Killed
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 2nd graf,``As many...' to UPDATE with search suspended until Sunday.
DOC.TEXT: A plane performing acrobatics crashed into a northern California lake Saturday, and officials said at least six people on board were killed. As many as 10 people may have been on the plane and there were no known survivors, said Craig Doan, air traffic specialist with the Federal Aviation Administration in nearby Ukiah. Authorities suspended the search shortly before midnight, and planned to resume Sunday. The Korean War-vintage PIIV twin engine plane crashed into the west end of Clear Lake, about 50 yards from shore, said Doan. Clear Lake is about 100 miles north of San Francisco. FAA authorities in Los Angeles said they believe 10 people were aboard, but they had not confirmed that number, Doan said. Another FAA official in Ukiah, Bev Clark, later said six fatalities had been confirmed. She said divers were searching for other possible victims. The pilot was buzzing seaplanes meeting at the ``fly-in'' sponsored by the Skylark Motel, witnesses said. The aircraft was not part of the seaplane convention, a spokeswoman for the motel said. The owner of the plan was not immediately know, Lakeport sheriff's said. An investigator from the National Transportation Safety Board was to arrive Sunday from Los Angeles, along with officials from FAA Flight Standards in Sacramento, the FAA said. Witnesses watching the seaplane ``fly-in'' said the pilot was buzzing planes in the water and then did a barrel roll and crashed, leaving only 1 foot of the craft visible above water. ``It didn't look like a seaplane. When it would go by, he would put a cloud of smoke nd then go away and straight up through the sky. This guy we were sitting with said, `He can't do that in that kind of plane,''' said Debbie Fields, owner of On the Waterfront boat rental. The plane leveled off and then ``did something similar to a barrel roll. There was no hope for him then; he went straight down,'' Fields added. The plane is a large patrol aircraft used in anti-submarine warfare, Doan said. Authorities had not determined the identification number or where the craft was based, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, South Korea To Establish Diplomatic Ties, Diplomats Say
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Meeting scheduled at noon EDT
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and South Korea on Sunday will announce plans to establish diplomatic relations, South Korean diplomats said. The South Korean diplomats said their foreign minister, Choi Ho-joong, and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze would make the announcement after their meeting at the United Nations. The diplomats, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said no date had been set for establishment of ties, but it would be soon, possibly as early as November. Soviet diplomats said only that the Soviet-Korean meeting would be ``important.'' South Korea has been pushing for ties with the Soviet Union, a long-time ally and friend of its rival North Korea, one of the last bastions of hardline Communism, resisting the worldwide wave of democratic movements. The Soviet Union, which is undergoing political liberalization, also has been improving its relations with South Korea, and the Moscow government is eager for enhanced trade and economic cooperation to help bolster the Soviet economy. The two Koreas have been arch-enemies since the Korean peninsula was divided after World War II. They fought a 1950-53 war, and hundreds of thousands of troops are positioned along their border. The move is expected to enhance a South Korean bid to join the United Nations. Communist North Korea has opposed separate entry of the two nations on the divided peninsula and says separate admission would only reaffirm division. North Korea and South Korea currently hold non-voting observer status at the United Nations. The Soviet decision would leave China as North Korea's most powerful Communist ally. But China, too, has been cautiously improving its relations with South Korea and also is interested in South Korean investment and technology. South Korean diplomats have said they would only seek U.N. admission if they are certain that China, a permanent member of the Security Council with veto power, would not oppose them. With the crumbling of the Soviet Bloc, more Eastern European nations are seeking normalization of relations with South Korea.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Budget Bargainers All But Finish Tentative Budget Deal
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOPS with 8th grafs with congressional sources confirming budget deal
DOC.TEXT: Congressional leaders said they have all but reached a tentative agreement with the Bush administration to slash $500 billion off the federal deficit, a deal that would stave off a chaotic shrinking of government services on Monday, officials said Sunday. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the budget negotiators have resolved all the tax questions and other issues but still have some questions about reforming the budget process that they need to discuss with Bush. Fitzwater said only technical questions remained to be resolved. He said the president will meet with negotiators at 12:30 p.m. ``to hopefully conclude that final issue and get an agreement after that.'' Bush has insisted all along that he wanted the budget deal to include long-term reform that will tighten controls on the budgetary process. Other officials said negotiators disposed of two of the toughest issues - capital gains tax cuts and higher taxes on Social Security recipients - by removing them from the package. ``They're done, gone,'' said one Democratic participant who demanded anonymity. President Bush was scheduled to fly back to Washington from New York by early afternoon. He had been in New York to deliver speeches and to meet with foreign officials. Bargainers were gathering in the Capitol Sunday morning to try to nail down the final details of the agreement. Still outstanding were procedural questions about how to guarantee agreed-on spending limits in the last several years of the five-year package. Without a deal, deep cuts in many federal programs are due to take effect Monday. White House officials said privately Saturday night that if the president returned to the nation's capital, it would be to put the final seal on the major deficit cutting deal he and congressional leaders have been seeking for more than four months. The officials said Bush would leave for Washington after speaking to the United Nations children's summit. He was traveling on a small Air Force jet and planned to later return to New York, where he had meetings scheduled with nine foreign heads of state. Bush's move came after congressional and White House leaders worked into the early morning hours in search of a deficit-reduction agreement that would avert widespread curtailment of government services Monday morning. The negotiators planned to return later in the day. ``We've made a lot of progress. We just don't have a deal yet,'' Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole said early Sunday at the end of a 13-hour negotiating session. A spokesman for House Speaker Thomas S. Foley described the previous 24 hours as the most successful since these talks began in May. Talks were scheduled to resume at midday. If an agreement is reached, the House and Senate would consider stopgap legislation later in the day to give the government new spending authority for the budget year that begins Monday and to postpone furloughs of federal workers and cuts in government services for three or four days. White House officials had previously indicated Bush would return to Washington to announce his backing for an agreement if one were reached. Democratic and Republican leaders have acknowledged that the deficit-reduction plan they are writing will be unpopular. But they are betting lawmakers will swallow hard and accept it as better than the alternative of deep, arbitrary cuts in many programs. During the Saturday session, aides said, negotiators agreed to eliminate from the package a proposed increase in the portion of Social Security benefits subject to income tax. Democratic negotiators especially had been cautioned by party members that they could not accept such a tax increase on retirees. The bargainers also put aside President Bush's proposed tax cut on capital gains, which are profits from the sale of investments. Democrats insisted they could not accept that reduction - whose benefits would go chiefly to higher-income Americans - unless other taxes on those same people were raised to make up the difference. The package would reduce the deficit by about $50 billion during the budget year that begins Monday and by another $450 billion during the following four years. Key parts of the package would: -Raise taxes on gasoline, all forms of energy, cigarettes, liquor, wine, beer and airline tickets. -Impose a new 10 percent tax on part of the price of expensive cars, electronic equipment, furs, jewelry and other ``luxuries.'' -Boost the monthly premium retirees pay for Medicare doctors' services. -Cut military spending by $170 billion over five years. -Reduce outlays for education, space, the court system and many other programs by $120 billion. Early today Bush and British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher attended a service in a private chapel at St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church, a landmark Byzantine edifice just across the street from the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, where the president is staying in New York.

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead, 19 Injured In Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: A minibus carrying passengers to a mountain village lost its brakes and plunged into a ravine, killing four people and injuring 19, police said Sunday. A 5-year-old girl was among those killed in the accident Saturday night, police said. Police said the vehicle was headed for the nearby village of Mananawan, south of Manila, when the accident occurred. No further details were given.

DOC.HEAD: Man Surrenders After Threatening Family, Wounding Policemen
DOC.TEXT: An unemployed house painter surrendered Sunday after a 24-hour siege during which he shot and wounded five policemen and threatened to kill himself and his family. Patrick Moesta, 33, entered the apartment of his estranged wife in suburban Paris at midday Saturday. Neighbors called the police when they heard an argument. Moesta began firing buckshot from a hunting rifle, wounding five officers and a neighbor. Two policemen were hospitalized with wounds in the face. An elite police unit used in hostage situations sealed off the apartment building. Moesta surrendered after talking with a prosecutor. His wife, 10-year-old daughter and 8-year-old son were unhurt. Moesta reportedly was distraught at the possibility that he would be separated from his two children if his wife divorced him. He was charged several weeks ago with attempted murder of his wife, but was allowed to remain free against the advice of the prosecution.

DOC.HEAD: Two Officers, Two Kurdish Guerrillas Die in Clashes
DOC.TEXT: Two Kurdish guerrillas and two army officers were killed in a clashin southeastern Turkey, the semi-official Anatolia News Agency reported Sunday. It said the incident took place Saturday night in Van province. The guerrillas in the region belong to the Kurdish Labor Party, a Marxist group trying to set up an independent state in southeastern Turkey. About 2,500 soldiers, guerrillas and civilians have died in clashes since 1984. Ethnic Kurds comprise about one-fifth of Turkey's population of 55 million.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pirates Kill Eight Ferry Passengers
DOC.TEXT: Armed pirates boarded a ferry, killed eight passengers and tossed the bodies into the river, a newspaper reported Sunday. The ferry was traveling from the southern port of Chittagong to the island town of Sandwip when an unknown number of pirates boarded it Thursday, the Bengali-language Sangbad newspaper said. It said 11 of the 90 passengers on board jumped into the water and were later rescued by fishermen. It quoted passengers as saying the eight were killed for resisting looting by the pirates. The pirates took the ferry to a shoal on the nearby Bay of Bengal and then fled, the newspaper reported.

DOC.HEAD: Four Dead, 13 Injured In Storm
DOC.TEXT: A powerful tropical storm swept through western and central Japan on Sunday, leaving four dead and 13 injured, police said. The tropical storm was downgraded from Typhoon Gene, which had winds of up to 86 miles per hour before it landed in western Japan Sunday morning, they said. Airline and railway officials said more than 200,000 people were affected by the cancellation of flights and train service as the tropical storm struck near Chiba, 21 miles east of Tokyo. The storm, with maximum winds of 43 mph, was heading northeast along Japan's Pacific coast, weather forecasters said. A National Police official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said 23 houses were destroyed by wind and landslides and more than 4,000 others were flooded throughout the country. Among the hardest hit was Miyazaki prefecture on Japan's southern island of Kyushu, where two people were killed when their houses were destroyed by landslides and another died after falling into a river, the official said. A 49-year-old man was killed in a landslide in Shizuoka, 90 miles west of Tokyo, he said. A Japan Railways official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said fierce winds and rain forced the railroad to cancel 96 high-speed ``bullet'' trains on the line between Tokyo and Osaka. The official said many local trains also were halted by the rain. All Nippon Airways canceled 90 domestic flights and Japan Airlines canceled 10 flights from Tokyo's Haneda airport, airline officials said. The Maritime Safety Agency, Japan's coast guard, said there were no reports of damage to ships.

DOC.HEAD: 3-Year-Old Can Recite Greek Alphabet, Read At Second-Grade Level
DOC.TEXT: Troy and Trina Kinast have to watch what they say around their 3-year-old son. Seth Kinast, according to his parents, can already recite the Greek alphabet, say the English alphabet forward and backward, count in Spanish, German and English, read at a second-grade level, identify countries on a globe, recite the books of the New Testament and keep up with adult conversations. Seth began saying ``Mommy'' and ``Daddy'' at about 8 months. At 16 months, he named the letters of the alphabet. At 22 months, he read magazine headlines at a grocery store, the Kinasts said. The couple read books to the unborn child because they heard it could stimulate letter and sound recognition. After Seth was born, they read or sang to him as they rocked him to sleep. ``Now we read to him before naps and bedtime,'' Kinast said. ``He has a stack of books by his bed, and he reads to himself. Sometimes at 11:30 p.m., we have to tell him to quit, but he always says, `Just one more.''' More than 800 books line the shelves in Seth's bedroom. Recently, Seth and his grandmother were getting ready to play ``Sorry!'' when his grandmother realized she didn't have her glasses. Seth read her the rules from the game box, Kinast said. The Kinasts already have decided to teach Seth at home and provide lessons in piano and organ. And they're beginning to teach younger brother Nathan, 8 months old. Kinast is a math instructor at Wichita State University; Mrs. Kinast stays home with the children. He said he and his wife are not overdrilling Seth or forcing him to learn things against his will. ``It's like a game,'' he said. ``He learned the ABC song, and then we learned the letters backward by putting them to the song. ... When we doodle, we doodle shapes, letters and designs. When we play hide and seek, we count in German.''

DOC.HEAD: Six Killed, 24 Hurt In Bus Crash
DOC.TEXT: A bus carrying elderly French tourists veered off a highway and into a gully Sunday, killing six passengers and injuring 24, police said. Thirteen of the injured were seriously hurt and taken to nearby hospitals in the Eastern Pyrenees region of southernmost France. The group had spent the night in Andorra, a tiny country wedged between France and Spain. The crash occurred near Perpignan, a city on the Mediterranean coast just north of the border with Spain. According to police, the bus driver reported that the brake system began to fail and the bus skidded along a soft shoulder of the road before plunging about 16 feet down an embankment. The driver was slightly hurt. The passengers were from the area around Calais, an English Channel port. Those killed, four women and two men, were believed to be in their 60s, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Prospect of U.S. Ground Offensive Seen To Be Still Weeks Away
DOC.TEXT: In the first days after President Bush ordered American troops into the Persian Gulf, Washington was awash with speculation about the size of the deployment: 10,000 troops? 50,000? Now, with Operation Desert Shield into its ninth week, the magnitude of the U.S. military buildup is clear: roughly 165,000-plus soldiers, sailors and airmen; 420 warplanes; 50 warships. And it's still growing. Even with this formidable presence, military analysts say it will be another few weeks before the Pentagon has arrayed enough heavy armor to launch a successful ground offensive against Iraq. Complicating the military equation is the continued buildup of Iraqi forces in Kuwait and southern Iraq - estimated by the Pentagon to total 430,000 men as of Sept. 25. ``We're a long way from having any capability to do anything other than behave in a defensive way,'' said Jack Merritt, a retired Army general and former U.S. representative to the NATO Military Committee. In ordering U.S. forces to Saudi Arabia on Aug. 7, Bush said their mission was to deter an Iraqi attack on the desert kingdom and, in the event the Iraqis invaded, to defend the Saudi oil fields. The president has not ruled out an offensive strike to try to dislodge Iraqi forces from Kuwait, and Defense Secretary Dick Cheney said Friday it seemed increasingly likely that Saddam Hussein woul lash out with military force in response to the U.N. trade embargo against his export-dependent country. American forces currently are deployed in defensive positions in and around Saudi Arabia. Three U.S. Marine formations totalling more than 45,000 personnel are in position along Saudi Arabia's gulf coastline, and three Army heavy armored units - two brigades of the 24th Mechanized Infantry Division, plus the 197th Mechanized Infantry Brigade - are fully deployed in defensive positions in northeastern Saudi Arabia. These components, which currently form the backbone of U.S. ground forces in Saudi Arabia, are greatly outnumbered by personnel and heavy armor on the Iraqi side. ``I suspect it'll be the first of November before there is really an offensive capability'' by the American forces, said James Blackwell, a military analyst at the Center for Strategic and International Studies, a Washington think tank. The U.S. Air Force already has gained numerical superiority over Iraq. There are at least 420 U.S. warplanes - including 14 F-111 long-range bombers and 22 F-117A stealth fighter-bombers - deployed at about 30 bases in and around Saudi Arabia. The overwhelming U.S. air power facing Iraqi forces is built around Airborne Warning and Control System planes that carry a saucer-like radar above the fuselage and communications devices that link the field of battle into a single picture.
