Five American and five Saudi AWACS are in the area now. The U.S. Navy also has several Hawkeyes, similar aircraft that take off from aircraft carriers to perform radar and communications roles. The U.S. naval fleet in the region totals about 50 vessels, including four aircraft carriers. The battleship USS Wisconsin, armed with 32 Tomahawk cruise missiles, is in the gulf, and an estimated eight nuclear submarines are lurking in the area. The Army, Air Force and Navy also have placed special operations forces in the gulf. These forces are trained in unconventional warfare tactics such as sabotage. Also arrayed against Iraq are a variety of ground, air and naval forces from more than 20 other countries, including Britain, France, Egypt, Syria and Morocco. Blackwell said the sealift of American military hardware is running at least a couple of weeks behind schedule, mainly because of breakdowns by transport ships. Even so, additional ground units are beginning to arrive in Saudi Arabia, including: -The 3rd Armored Cavalry Regiment from Fort Bliss, Texas, which is equipped with hundreds of M-1 Abrams tanks and Bradley Fighting Vehicles. The lead elements of the 4,500-man unit left for Saudi Arabia on Wednesday, according to Fort Bliss spokesman Brad Rose. The full unit should be there within two weeks. -One brigade of the ``Hell on Wheels'' 2nd Armored Division, totaling about 3,000 soldiers, from Fort Hood, Texas, began heading for the Saudi desert last week, according to base spokesman Maj. Jesse Seigal. All are expected to meet up with their equipment, which is arriving by sea, within 10 days. -Two brigades of the 1st Cavalry Division, totaling about 6,000 soldiers, also from Fort Hood, began leaving for Saudi Arabia last week and the full force should be in place there in about 10 days. -Also en route to Saudi Arabia from Fort Hood are at least 2,000 members of the 13th Corps Support Command and several hundred members each from the 15th Military Intelligence Battalion and the 89th Military Police Brigade, Seigal said. The earliest U.S. ground forces sent to Saudi Arabia were the 82nd Airborne Division from Fort Bragg, N.C., and the 101st Airborne Division from Fort Campbell, Ky. They are the two most rapidly deployable of the Army's major units. The Pentagon has announced no intention of deploying additional Army divisions. Of the U.S.-based forces, the only major units still available for heavy ground operations in Saudi Arabia would be the 1st Infantry Division from Fort Riley, Kan.; the 4th Infantry Division from Fort Carson, Colo.; and the 5th Infantry Division from Fort Polk, La.

DOC.HEAD: Rapist Says Judge Who Ordered Probation Ruined His Life
DOC.TEXT: A rapist says his life was ruined by a judge who called the victim a ``pitiful woman'' as he rejected a prison sentence worked out in a plea bargain. ``He has created a living hell for me,'' said Mark Edward McCulloch, who accepted a 4{-year prison term offered by prosecutors but was placed on probation for two years. ``I was ready to go to jail.'' McCulloch now fears for his safety, saying, ``I can't walk out of the door without fear of losing my life. He put me at risk. Anyone can take a shot at me.'' Gov. Bob Martinez and others called for the resignation of Seminole Circuit Judge Kenneth Leffler after the sentencing, but the judge is returning to the bench Monday under a self-imposed limit restricting his cases to civil suits. McCulloch rented a room from the victim, a 40-year-old Casselberry woman, for two years and accepted full responsibility for the rape April 9. The woman said her tenant became infatuated and obsessed with her. Leffler, who presided over the woman's 1987 divorce trial, said at the sentencing, ``I'm almost of the belief that she is a victimizer of men.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: Pianist Van Cliburn will celebrate his mother's birthday in style - by underwriting the Oct. 12 and 13 performances of the Fort Worth Ballet. Cliburn, known for doing things in a big way, also will invite everybody in the audience at the Fort Worth-Tarrant County Convention Center Theatre on Oct. 12 to have a slice of his mother's birthday cake. Rildia Bee Cliburn will be 94 on Oct. 14. The mother and son are featured in the October issue of Vogue. He is scheduled to perform Oct. 27 with the Leningrad Philharmonic at the Tilles Center in Brookville, N.Y. Cliburn, who ended a decade-long sabbatical last year, became an instant celebrity when he won the prestigious Tchaikovsky Competition in Moscow in 1958. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Dustin Hoffman will play Captain Hook and Robin Williams will portray Peter Pan in the upcoming movie adventure-comedy ``Hook'' directed by Steven Spielberg. Hoffman was most recently seen in ``Dick Tracy,'' portraying the unintelligible Mumbles. ``Hook' is a variation on Peter Pan, but it's not the same Peter Pan story that Michael Jackson has been trying to make for five years, Entertainment Weekly magazine reported, citing an unidentified source. ``Hook'' is scheduled to begin filming early next year in the Virgin Islands. --- GDANSK, Poland (AP) - Solidarity leader and presidential candidate Lech Walesa celebrated his 47th birthday and married off his oldest son on the same day. Bogdan Walesa, 21, wed Agnieszka Drozdowska in a crowded ceremony on Saturday at the Oliwa Cathedral near Walesa's home in this Baltic port city. On Sunday, the day after his birthday, the Solidarity chief and father of eight received congratulations from fellow worshipers after Mass at St. Brygida's Church. The church is a few blocks from the Gdansk Shipyard where he led strikes in 1980 and 1988 that ultimately changed the political face of Poland. His is running to succeed President Wojciech Jaruzelski in elections tentatively set for Nov. 25. Referring to his campaign, he said he hoped ``a lively sea wind will keep coming to Poland from Gdansk as it has for the past 10 years.'' --- RENO, Nev. (AP) - Her court case against Judas Priest may not have been a hit with the judge, but lawyer Vivian Lynch is hoping a new country song she penned will reach the top of the charts. Lynch recently represented the families of two Sparks, Nev., youths who shot themselves after listening to a record by the English heavy metal rock band. The families contended subliminal messages were responsible for the deaths of their sons, but Washoe District Judge Jerry Whitehead ruled against them Aug. 24. A self-described amateur guitarist-songwriter, Lynch said she wrote the song ``No More Deadly Music'' in 20 minutes immediately after losing the Judas Priest case. The song takes aim at themes of drugs, sex and violence. One verse goes: ``I won't sing of lust or violence, talk of crack or speed or weed. I won't tell you death's the answer, or sing of wicked Satan's creed.'' Lynch, 50, said the song is in the hands of a Nashville music lawyer. ``I have been assured that somebody probably will record it,'' she said. --- SAN JUAN, Puerto Rico (AP) - Archbishop Desmond Tutu says South African President F.W. de Klerk deserves praise for progress in dismantling apartheid. ``He has been remarkably courageous, and it would be churlish to say that he does not deserve to be praised. And I have been praising him all over the place,'' Tutu said. He made his comments after a speech to 1,400 members of the Puerto Rican Bar Association at their annual meeting Saturday. But the prelate urged the United States to retain economic sanctions until the major pillars of apartheid are removed. ``Sanctions must remain until the process is irreversible,'' Tutu said. ``It is economic sanctions that have brought us to the point we have reached.'' Tutu, leader of the 2.6 million-member Anglican Church of the Province of Southern Africa and winner of the 1984 Nobel Peace Prize, arrived Friday for a weekend visit to Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands. On Sunday, he celebrated a communion service with a Spanish, English and African flavor at Puerto Rico's Episcopal Cathedral and had lunch with Puerto Rico Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - Singer Kenny Loggins is asking $14 million for his nearly 20-acre estate in the exclusive Santa Barbara County community of Montecito, according to a published report. Loggins, whose new album ``Leap of Faith'' is due out early next year, and his wife, Eva, have filed for divorce, ending their 12-year marriage, the Los Angeles Times said Sunday. They had the home built two years ago after touring Italy with their architect, Barry Berkus. Berkus built the compound to take advantage of the ocean and mountain views. The compound 100 miles northwest of Los Angeles features a nine-bedroom villa with 10{ bathrooms, five kitchens, three laundry rooms, seven fireplaces and garages for six cars. In addition to the 8,500-square-foot main house, there is a guest house, pool house, caretaker's cottage, sports complex and kennel. The property also has a well, stream, pool, pond, spa, two waterfalls and fountains.

DOC.HEAD: Filipino Workers At U.S. Bases Go On Strike
DOC.TEXT: More than 22,000 Filipino civilian employees at six U.S. military bases went on strike Sunday over pay. They were protesting wage ceilings mandated by the U.S. Congress that they said violated their collective bargaining agreement. The Federation of Filipino Civilian Employees Association decided on the strike Sept. 18 after U.S. authorities refused to implement a promised 18 percent pay increase. After the collective bargaining agreement was reached earlier this year, Congress imposed a 3 percent ceiling on pay increases for federal employees, including those outside the United States, in a budget-cutting measure. A U.S. spokesman, Lt. Cmdr. Kevin Mukri, said the U.S. military had drafted contingency plans in case of a strike but he did not elaborate. The Pacific Stars and Stripes newspaper, an unofficial publication of the U.S. military, said the command had advertised for dependents and retired service members to fill the labor pool.

DOC.HEAD: Dog Found After Living A Year With Transient
DOC.TEXT: Amy Ritter couldn't have dreamed of a better birthday present - the return of her long-lost pooch, Maggie, who had been given up for dead nearly two years ago. The child, who turns 10 on Wednesday, was reunited with her pup Saturday after her father stumbled across the pet playing behind a Glendale junk shop with its most recent owner - a homeless man. The family live in an unincorporated area near Glendale. Thomas Ritter knew the dog was his daughter's when he spotted an old BB-pellet wound in the dog's neck. After paying the panhandler $10 for his troubles, Ritter took Maggie back, brought her to the vet, cleaned her up and brought her home. ``All I could do was just stare at her,'' said Amy. ``I didn't know what to think.'' Despite a bad eye infection and being worn out after 21 months of street living, Maggie instantly recognized Amy, leaping into her arms and licking her face. Amy had been heartbroken about the loss of her puppy. ``She never got over it,'' her father said. ``Every time someone says they saw a `Benji-type' dog, which is just what Maggie looked like, I ... had to check it out. ``We just think the Lord is watching over us, if you want to know the truth. Otherwise, something like this just could never happen.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Trying for Another Launch, with Another Shuttle
DOC.TEXT: After months of embarrassing failures, NASA will try again this week to launch a shuttle, this time with a nuclear-powered satellte that will study the sun's uncharted poles. Optimism abounds, and with some reason: The shuttle scheduled to lift off Saturday morning - Discovery - is the most recent spaceship to have flown and the only one in which fuel leaks have not been found. ``Right now, I don't even feel weather can hold us up because we've been just doing everything right on time,'' said astronaut Bruce Melnick, one of five men assigned to the upcoming mission. Columbia has been grounded by dangerous hydrogen leaks since May, Atlantis since June. NASA tried four times to send Columbia on an astronomy mission before stopping two weeks ago to make way for Discovery's high-priority flight. NASA has until Oct. 23 to launch Discovery with the European sun probe, named for the legendary Greek adventurer Ulysses. Otherwise, the $750 million mission will have to be put on hold for 13 months, when Earth is aligned properly again with the sun and Jupiter. The four-day mission already is more than four years late. It originally was scheduled for May 1986, but was delayed indefinitely following the Challenger explosion earlier that year. The fact that Discovery has ``a real clean history'' is encouraging, said astronaut Tom Akers. Discovery's April flight that put the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit was smooth and trouble-free. The mission's success was overshadowed two months later, however, by discovery of a defective mirror on the $1.5 billion telescope. New fuel lines have been installed between the orbiter and external tank, the area where hydrogen leaked in the other two shuttles, NASA officials said. But little work was performed in Discovery's engine compartment following the last flight, lessening the likelihood that any repair work has caused any damage. ``I don't have any problems at all worrying about the vehicle,'' said Akers, who like Melnick will be making his first shuttle flight. ``The most apprehension that I feel is on my own personal performance. I want to make sure I don't mess up.'' Six hours into the flight, as Discovery orbits 184 miles above Earth, Akers will switch on the system releasing the satellite from the cargo bay. A series of rapid engine firings will send the 807-pound spacecraft hurtling toward Jupiter at a speed of 34,450 mph, making it the fastest manmade object in relation to Earth. Ulysses is expected to reach Jupiter in February 1992. The giant planet's gravity will whip Ulysses into an unprecedented orbit over the solar poles. The closest the spacecraft will come to the sun is about 120 million miles - 27 million miles farther away from the sun than it is now on the launch pad. Ulysses is expected to pass over the sun's south pole in 1994 and the north pole the following year. ``Almost anything we learn with Ulysses will be real learning. It's new. We've never been there before,'' said Edgar Page, Ulysses' science coordinator for the European Space Agency, which is conducting the mission with NASA. Scientists plan to examine the sun's corona and magnetic field and solar wind and flares. So far, measurements have been made only over the sun's equator. To reach its destination, Ulysses will use electricity generated from nearly 23.7 pounds of decaying plutonium-238. The only other time such a generator has flown on a shuttle was in October 1989, when Atlantis carried the Jupiter-bound Galileo into space. Environmental activists opposed to nuclear-powered spacecraft asked a federal judge in Washington on Friday to stop the launch. NASA, which says it has no other option, has until Tuesday to respond. The activists contend a Challenger-like accident could shower deadly plutonium over Florida. NASA officials insist the chance of that happening is extremely small because of the generator's numerous protective layers. NASA's Dudley McConnell, author of an environmental impact statement on Ulysses, said there is a less than one in 1 million chance of an accident that would result in a plutonium-related death. The slight chance of such an accident odds won't keep the astronauts' families away Saturday. ``My family is going to be down there in Florida standing underneath Discovery waving goodbye as we go off the launch pad, so I don't have any problems,'' said Discovery's commander Dick Richards. ``I am confident in this system and that it doesn't provide any hazard to anybody on the ground.''

DOC.HEAD: Judges Say They're Overworked, Underpaid, Concerned About Security
DOC.TEXT: Overworked, underpaid compared with their peers in private practice and facing increasing threats from drug traffickers and disgruntled defendants, federal judges are facing a crisis in the judiciary. The situation is so bad that veteran jurists are resigning and the brightest lawyers are refusing to take their places, saying the exalted status of a federal judge can't make up for what they consider to be a life under siege. One of the most respected judges in the frantic Southern District of Florida resigned last week, citing pressures and finances. U.S. District Judge Thomas E. Scott of Miami decided to retire from the bench at the age of 42 after five years as a circuit judge and five more on the federal level. The departure of a man widely thought of as having one of the top legal minds in Florida was taken as an ominous sign in Miami's legal community. ``In losing Tom Scott, we're losing the equivalent of two judges,'' said Chief District Judge James Lawrence King. ``If Congress doesn't act soon, it will leave the judiciary of South Florida tattered and torn.'' Judicial workloads have more than doubled since 1969, with so many drug cases clogging the courts that civil litigants must wait years for a trial date. ``Nobody would have taken this job unless they anticipated working very hard and being underpaid, but there are limits,'' said Chief Judge Thomas C. Platt of the Eastern District in New York, where where 12 judges grappled with 1,010 new criminal cases this year, or more than 84 new cases each. According to figures from the Judicial Conference of the United States, only six federal judges resigned or retired from the bench from 1958 to 1973. But from 1974 to 1988, 59 federal judges left the bench. Across the nation, some judges live under armed guard 24 hours a day, and at least 295 threats against federal judges have been made since October 1989, according to the U.S. Marshals Service. Judge Scott will more than double his $96,600 salary after he joins the Miami law firm of Steel, Hector and Davis on Oct. 31. But he said his comparative pay as a judge was only one of his frustrations. In his resignation speech Thursday, Scott appealed for more support for judges in the war on drugs, calling them ``unsung heroes in an ongoing ordeal.'' ``Constantly at odds with a Congress that does not address its needs and problems ... they face a daily struggle against threats of physical violence, overburdened crime calendars and limited resources,'' he said. While authorities believe a racial extremist was responsible for the package bomb that killed 11th Circuit Judge Robert Vance in Georgia last December, judges in Florida are more concerned with international criminals who are used to terrorizing or bribing judges in their own countries, Scott said in a recent interview. ``When you enter into the world of drug traffickers and the money and violence they represent, it's very scary,'' said Scott, who drives a different route home each day from the federal courthouse in Miami. ``There doesn't have to be a threat,'' he added. ``You know that one day, one of these decisions is going to come back to haunt you.'' Neal Sonnett, the immediate past president of the National Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers, said Scott's departure is a symbol of how drug cases have overwhelmed the system. ``He worked enormously hard, and this district is the busiest in the country,'' Sonnett said. ``(But) all the judges down here spend 70-80 percent of their time on drug cases. That's bound to wear on you.'' The Bush administration is expanding U.S. attorneys' offices nationwide, but judges say the federal bench hasn't grown to meet the demand in criminal and civil matters, especially in drug-entry states like Florida, Texas, California and New York. The load could be eased in some districts under a Senate proposal to create 77 new judgeships and reduce the costs and delays of civil litigation. The bill, sponsored by Judiciary Chairman Joseph Biden, D-Del., and Sen. Strom Thurmond, R-S.C., passed the committee in July. Federal judge's salaries are also due for a rise - to $120,800 in 1991, if the Gulf crisis and deficit-reduction battles don't prompt Congress to rescind the pay raise. Sonnett said holding down salaries would only exacerbate a ``double-barreled problem.'' ``The best judges are starting to leave, and the best lawyers are no longer interested in taking their place,'' he said. ``You run the risk of reducing the quality of the federal bench, and allowing politics to creep in. The federal judiciary should be above that.''

DOC.HEAD: Washington, D.C., Sure Isn't Weare, N.H.
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: David Souter may be able to maintain his modest lifestyle as a Supreme Court justice, but there's no doubt that moving from Weare, N.H., to Washington, D.C., will require some adjustments. If confirmed by the Senate this month as expected, Souter will go from a community of 6,000 to a metropolitan area of more than 2.5 million, from negligible crime to one of the nation's highest murder rates. And most important to Souter, from privacy into the public eye. ``Do you think that this guy who lives on a dirt road in Weare, New Hampshire, can possibly understand the problems of modern society?'' longtime friend Bill Glahn said in a parody of attitudes he's encountered. Early media portraits of Souter after his nomination to the Supreme Court focused on his unmown lawn, old car and paint-chipped mailbox. Weekly visits to his mother were noted, as was his bachelor status. Many observers were concerned that his writings as a state judge didn't shed enough light on how he would vote on federal constitutional issues. They worried that living in a state with no big cities and few minorities had sheltered Souter from such realities as AIDS, discrimination and urban crime. Both liberals and conservatives called him a risk. Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., said the early media zoom lens on Souter created a phony image that changed during the confirmation hearings. ``To some extent, what those stories demonstrated was what I consider to be the arrogance of this city and the media, who unfortunately have become part of the establishment and don't know it,'' Rudman said in a telephone interview from Washington. Glahn, a Manchester lawyer, acknowledged that Souter's Weare-to-Washington transfer will require adjustments. ``Where he is there's no noise at night - sometimes no lights at night - no safety problems,'' said Glahn. ``For David to drive from Weare to Concord, there are probably two stop lights.'' Glahn said remaining in the public eye may be the most difficult thing for Souter to become accustomed to. ``He becomes of necessity a public figure,'' Glahn said. ``He's a very private man, and a very humble man. I don't think he likes the notoriety.'' Souter leaves his Weare farmhouse, valued at around $150,000, for one of the nation's most expensive housing markets. His salary as an associate justice will be $118,600 and will increase to $148,300 in January. As a judge on the 1st U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals in Boston, where he served since May, Souter received $102,000 annually. All but one of the U.S. Supreme Court justices live in the Virginia suburbs of Washington, where four-bedroom homes in desirable areas average $300,000-$500,000 and can go well above the $1 million mark. Rudman said Souter initially will find a place near the court, presumably on Capitol Hill, so he can concentrate on work. Souter, Rudman said, will maintain the same ascetic lifestyle. ``David Souter is not going to change. He's not going to start being on the Style pages of The Washington Post,'' Rudman said. ``I can tell you that David Souter wants to live a very quiet and modest life down here.'' An avid hiker, Souter, bereft of New Hampshire's White Mountains, probably will find solace in Virginia's nearby Blue Ridge range, Rudman said. Leaving friends will be difficult, Glahn said, even though Souter knows plenty of people in Washington. Souter, 51, may miss the closeness of New Hampshire communities, Glahn said. ``Everyone knows you. If you go to a store or restaurant, they know what you want for dinner,'' Glahn said. ``Those are the kinds of things they take for granted in a small town.'' Souter's Sunday visits to his mother, who lives in a retirement community in Concord, will be less frequent. Round-trip airfare starts at about $207. Glahn said Helen Souter, 82, will miss her son, but ``it will be a physical separation. ... She's not concerned about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Proposal: Create Enclave Within Detroit With Own Police, Schools
DOC.TEXT: A group of developers wants to block out urban crime by creating a town within the city, complete with its own police force and a school system that would require weapons searches and drug tests. The multimillion-dollar plan drafted by the developers called Partnership to Reinvest in Detroit's Excellence (PRIDE) has yet to be handed over to the city, but the mayor has expressed interest. The proposed new town, which would replace a crimbling neighborhood about 2 miles east of downtown, would be a place ``where practical family values can flourish in an atmosphere free of drugs, prostitution, pornography, gambling and other criminal activities,'' the proposal says. Mayor Coleman Young met with the developers a few months ago and asked for more details of the plan, city spokesman Bob Berg said Sunday. ``He backs the concept but he has not gone over the specifics,'' Berg said. ``He has been saying that he supports the idea of redeveloping that area.'' Among the developers taking part in the project are major companies such Michigan National Corp., a bank holding company; and Walbridge Aldinger, a leading construction company. The 740-acre community would border along the Detroit River near Belle Isle, according to the preliminary proposal obtained by The Detroit News and described in Sunday's editions. It would include the prime riverfront site of the former Uniroyal plant. The new town would be home to about 7,500 people and would have a minigovernment - under the city of Detroit - with authority to control the development and social programs, the plan says. The town would have a separate police department, but it was uncertain how the city would be involved in the hiring or running of the force. It would also have its own school district that would require checks for drugs and weapons. Several specifics were undetermined, including how the project would be funded. The developers said they would need complete cooperation with city, state and federal governments. The ``new town within a city'' concept was highlighted in a 1987 Detroit long-range plan, and Young has touted the idea for several years. ``This is hope,'' said David Baker Lewis, who helped draft the 1987 plan. ``I don't think all the ideas are feasible or would be embraced, but it's a start.'' The plan says the city would be asked to demolish buildings, relocate residents, clean up environmental hazards and relocate roads and utilities. When that is completed, the developers want the city to hand it over to them at no cost.

DOC.HEAD: Evacuees Return Home After Fire at Chemical Plant
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Tubilor cq in 2nd graf
DOC.TEXT: Nearly 1,000 people forced from their homes because of a fire at a nearby chemical plant were allowed to return home early Sunday, authorities said. Explosions and flames broke out about 6 p.m. Saturday at the Tubilor Protection of America plant, which makes polyvinyl chloride thread protectors for pipes used in the oil business. Officials said the fire was allowed to burn itself out to protect firefighters and to prevent chemical runoff. But fears of toxic fumes prompted authorities to order the evacuations of up to 1,000 people living nearby. Montgomery County officials said the residents were allowed to return home at about 1:30 a.m. Sunday. It was the Houston area's third industrial accident over the weekend. A propane leak earlier Saturday at a Shell Oil plant in Deer Park forced authorities to close a highway and order residents to stay inside. And a Norwegian tanker rammed a barge in the Houston Ship Channel late Friday, spilling nearly 30,000 gallons of partly refined crude oil into the water. It had largly evaporated by Sunday, but authorities said they would still have to test to see if a solvent in the oil had contaminated oyster reefs in the bay. Firefighters from about a dozen area departments battled the chemical plant blaze. Two firefighters who suffered smoke inhalation were treated and released, officials said. Several chemicals, including the flammable gas methyl chloride, are processed at the plant. Officials were investigating the cause of the fire at the chemical plant about 6 miles south of Magnolia, which is about 30 miles northwest of Houston.

DOC.HEAD: Search Continues For Victims In California Plane Crash
DOC.TEXT: A search resumed Sunday for the seventh victim of a plane crash that occurred when an uninvited aircraft appeared at a pilots' convention, gave an impromptu aerobatics display and plunged into a lake. Divers removed six bodies from the wreckage of the World War II Navy patrol plane, which broke apart on impact in Clear Lake before hundreds of stunned spectators Saturday afternoon. Believing a seventh person had been aboard, divers renewed the search Sunday morning, and authorities said they would try to pull the plane from the mud and murky water. Just before the crash, the bulky twin-engine Lockheed P2V Harpoon made four low passes over the crowd on the shore and the floating seaplanes meeting for the annual ``Seaplane Fly-In.'' The lake is about 100 miles north of San Francisco. ``When it would go by, he would put a cloud of smoke and then go away and straight up through the sky,'' said Debbie Fields, owner of a boat rental business. ``This guy we were sitting with said, `He can't do that in that kind of plane.''' The plane, believed to date from 1945, was not part of the seaplane convention, said Walter Windus, vice president of the Seaplane Pilots Association, an event sponsor. ``He was strictly an intruder,'' said Windus, who saw the crash. ``He saw an opportunity to show off and he took advantage of it. He was doing air maneuvers that were not appropriate to that type of aircraft.'' Convention organizers, he added, tried desperately to contact the pilot of the mystery plane by radio, planning to tell him to leave, but could not reach him. ``His behavior was so obnoxious,'' Windus said. ``I was going to tell him to go away or I was going to report him to the FAA.'' On its last pass, the plane ``did something similar to a barrel roll,'' Fields said, adding: ``There was no hope for him then. He went straight down.'' The plane crashed nose-first into six feet of water about 50 yards offshore on the lake's west end, said Walt Smith, a Federal Aviation Administration official based in nearby Santa Rosa. There were no survivors, he said. An investigator from the National Transportation Safety Board arrived from Los Angeles on Sunday morning. The plane had taken off from the Sonoma County Airport in Santa Rosa, south of Lake County, the Los Angeles Times quoted an unidentified FAA investigator as saying. Seven people were believed to be aboard, the newspaper said. Earlier reports had put the number on board to as many as 10. The names of the dead were not released, but officials told the paper the pilot was from Santa Rosa. Scott Landis, an amphibious-plane pilot from Long Beach attending the convention, said it appeared the Harpoon pilot may have pulled the nose of the plane up too high on the final pass, causing a stall. The plane ``turned over and the nose fell back toward the lake. The pilot tried to pull it out (of the dive) but there wasn't enough room,'' said Landis, who estimated the plane was between 1,500 and 2,000 feet when the nose dropped. ``He hit the water at between 150 and 200 miles per hour, probably,'' he added. ``The plane disintegrated.''

DOC.HEAD: Ukrainians March For Independence
DOC.TEXT: Tens of thousands of Ukrainian nationalists marched Sunday through Kiev, the republic's capital, calling for greater independence from the central government in Moscow. ``Mother Moscow: We want to be orphans,'' declared a banner held aloft by cheering protesters as they streamed along the city's main street, the Kreshchatik. The Ukraine is one of 13 Soviet republics that have taken steps toward greater autonomy from Moscow. The only one that has declared immediate independence is Lithuania. The Ukraine is the second-largest Soviet republic, after Russia, and is a key grain-growing area. Its parliament has declared sovereignty from Moscow and claims the right to overrule national laws. But nationalist groups want it to go further and take rapid moves toward secession. On Sunday, Interior Ministry troops in armored personnel carriers and riot police wearing bullet proof vests guarded key buildings and intersections, but the march was peaceful. No clashes were reported by the Soviet press or witnesses. ``The militia showed a benevolent attitude. Everything was very orderly, and there was no violence, no arrests,'' Oleg Zhukovsky, a spokesman for the Ukrainian nationalist group Rukh, said in a telephone interview after the rally. A coalition between Rukh and Ukrainian pro-democracy groups organized the demonstration to press a series of demands connected with autonomy from Moscow. The coalition also called a one-day warning strike for Monday. Among the demands are that Ukrainian men drafted by the Soviet army serve only in the Ukraine; that the Ukraine refuse to sign a new union treaty between the 15 Soviet republics; and that the Communist Party be declared a ``criminal organization'' and stripped of influence in all Ukrainian government organizations. Marchers yelled ``Down with the union treaty!'' and carried banners saying ``The Communist Party is a Criminal Clique'' and ``Long Live the Communist Party - at the Chernobyl Power Plant.'' A contingent from the Union of Independent Ukrainian Youth carried a symbolic coffin bearing a photo of Vladimir Lenin and the words ``Soviet Empire.'' Other protesters held a blue and yellow Ukrainian flag that had been blessed and presented to them by a Ukrainian Catholic priest. Turnout for the rally on a cold and overcast day was far below the 500,000 people that organizers had predicted. Grigory Maksimenko, a Rukh member, estimated the crowd at 100,000. Oles Fedorchuk, a spokesman for the Ukrainian Inter Party Assembly, put it at 75,000. The rally began at mid-afternoon in a square outside the city's main stadium, where Rukh said authorities had hastily ordered construction of a farmers' market in an attempt to disrupt the demonstration. After listening to speakers call for independence and condemn Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's attempts to forge a new union treaty, the demonstrators marched along the Kreshchatik toward Lenin Communist Youth League Square. Along the way, they passed two statues of Lenin, which nationalist groups are seeking to remove. Nationalist groups in several other republics also are pushing for independence. But regional officials have been reluctant to follow Lithuania's example, perhaps fearing economic sanctions similar to the ones that Gorbachev imposed on Lithuani last May. Lithuania was forced to close factories when the Kremlin cut off supplies of oil, natural gas and raw materials. The embargo was lifted in exchange for the Lithuanian parliament's agreement to suspend its March 11 declaration of independence pending negotiations, which are scheduled to begin Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: 14 Killed, Thousands Stranded By Floods in Bangladesh
DOC.TEXT: Flooding in dozens of northern villages killed 14 children, stranded tens of thousands of people and damaged crops across wide areas, news reports said Sunday. Nine children drowned in flooding over the past week in Sirajganj, 65 miles northwest of Dhaka, said United News of Bangladesh, a news agency. The rain-swollen Jamuna river overflowed its banks in Sirajganj last week, displacing about 300,000 villagers. Many took refuge on the roofs of their mud-and-straw houses. The Bengali-language daily Sangbad said five children drowned in northwestern Pabna and Manikganj districts after they fell off rooftops into floodwaters Friday and Saturday. The paper also said floods have affected about 100,000 people in the Sylhet and Netrokona districts in the northeast. Flooding in this low-lying delta nation annually kills hundreds of people. The region's worst recent floods killed 1,400 people in 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Rebel Leader Declares All-Out War, Cease-fire Broken
DOC.TEXT: Rebel leader Prince Johnson reportedly said peace talks had failed and declared ``all-out war'' Sunday on two armies already battling each other with mortars and gunfire. The five-nation West African force sent to end the war, meanwhile, reportedly sent warplanes on two bombing raids against positions of guerrilla chief Charles Taylor, a rival of Johnson. The West African force is the most powerful in Monrovia. The British Broadcasting Corp. said Johnson told journalists in Monrovia that negotiations had failed to end the 9-month-old conflict and ``violence is the only solution.'' The report said Johnson accused Taylor of breaking a cease-fire, and blamed the West African force for failing to enforce the truce. Johnson said he planned attacks on Taylor's forces and the presidential mansion where remanants of slain President Samuel Doe's forces were holed up, the BBC said. His announcement came after Doe's troops reportedly lobbed mortars into Johnson's territory. On Saturday, Johnson said he was going to attack and capture government troops, court-martial them for war crimes, and execute those found guilty. It was not known whether Taylor had ordered his men to break the cease-fire. Johnson on Saturday accused Taylor of violating the truce with two attacks on his forces in two days. The French news agency Agence France-Press reported that Taylor's rebels and Doe troops exchanged mortar fire and submachine gunfire within 500 yards of the heavily fortified executive mansion. It quoted some of Taylor's rebels as accusing Doe's soldiers of opening hostilities, but said others among them affirmed they had orders to fight to take the capital ``at all costs.'' Agence-France Presse has a correspondent traveling with the rebels. Taylor refuses to allow reporters with his fighters to cross the lines to other armies in Monrovia. Reporters based in areas controlled by Johnson, who holds most of downtown Monrovia, have been unable to cross to the rival rebel lines. Taylor announced a unilateral cease-fire on Sept. 22, but warned he would fight efforts to form any government except one led by him. The other three armies in Monrovia accepted the truce. But they have refused to accept Taylor as president. Taylor claims the presidency as a spoil of war because his army has overrun most of Liberia. He has said his government would be a temporary one that would organize fair elections. Johnson and Doe officers back West African plans to install an interim government which excludes the warring parties to help ensure fair balloting. Taylor has rejected a government named by Liberian opposition parties, businessmen and clergymen on Aug. 30, charging it is a puppet of the West Africans. Its leaders are waiting in neighboring Sierra Leone for fighting to die down. More than 5,000 civilians have been slaughtered by the three Liberian armies since Taylor invaded from Ivory Coast on Dec. 24 to oust Doe. Most victims lost their lives because of tribal affiliations.

DOC.HEAD: Papal Mass Opens Monthlong Synod on Formation of Priests
By STEPHEN R. WILSON
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II on Sunday opened a worldwide synod of bishops to discuss revitalizing the priesthood in the face of ``burnout,'' challenges to celibacy and a shrinking number of interested candidates. The pontiff inaugurated the monthlong assembly by celebrating a solemn Mass in St. Peter's Basilica for some 1,000 priests, bishops and cardinals from around the world. The synod, an advisory body that meets to discuss major issues in the Roman Catholic Church, was called by John Paul to discuss the formation of priests. ``Let me express the hope that your labors here will produce the abundant fruit which the ecclesiastical community is expecting,'' the pope, clad in gold robes and miter, said in his homily. He noted that bishops from China, Vietnam and Laos were missing from the gathering, and said he hoped they would join the synod later. No reason was given for the absence of bishops Jean Khamse of Laos and Cambodia, Paul Nguyen Van Hoa and Emmanuel Le Phong Thuan of Vietnam, and Lucas Liu Hsien-Tang of China. The Vatican says the church faces serious restrictions in those Communist countries. At the last synod in 1987, dealing with the laity, Vietnamese prelates arrived midway through the assembly. The synod is expected to focus on the difficulty in maintaining the church's rules that priests be celibate and foresake marriage ``in a world characterized by eroticism,'' as a working document put it. The rules themselves are not expected to be subjects for debate, however, as the pope has shown no indication they might be changed. Several sexual scandals have embarrased the church in recent months. The archbishop of Atlanta, Eugene A. Marino, resigned in July following revelations of a two-year ``intimate relationship'' with a young woman. In Newfoundland, Canada, a report in July by a church-appointed commission said priests had sexually abused boys in the province for more than a decade. ``Some priests question this requirement (celibacy) and some candidates leave formation for this reason,'' the working document said. It noted that in public opinion, celibacy is ``often incomprehensible and ridiculed.'' A priest who accepts celibacy ``is sometimes looked upon in a strange way,'' it said. ``In this situation a priest can become totally isolated and misunderstood to the point of becoming deeply demoralized,'' it said. ``In some cases, the crisis in the priestly identity can explain why priests leave the ministry.'' The Vatican cited ``the phenomenon of burnout, from which priests of all ages seem to suffer. They live in situations marked by tiredness, resignation, lack of creativity.'' The document lamented the shortage of priests and declining number of candidates in some countries. ``The shortage of priests carries the further consequence that those older priests who are still active might become overburdened, thus making them subject to stress and to approach their work ... simply as functionaries,'' it said. According to the latest statistics, there are 400,000 priests in the world, down from 406,000 five years ago. In the United States, students in the last four years of seminary numbered 3,698 this year, compared with 7,855 in 1968. The 200 bishops at the synod included Cardinal Joseph Bernardin of Chicago, Cardinal James Hickey of Washington, D.C., Archbishop Daniel Pilarczyk of Cincinnati and Bishop John Marshall of Burlington, Vermont.

DOC.HEAD: Indian Sealift Bringing Hundreds of Evacuees from Iraq to Dubai
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Stands for item listed on digest as AM-Gulf-Embargo
DOC.TEXT: An Indian vessel docked at the southern Persian Gulf port of Dubai on Sunday with 705 weary evacuees from Iraq aboard. It was the second time in three weeks that Baghdad had allowed such a sealift. Another Indian ship, the Akbar, with more than 1,800 people aboard, was en route to Dubai from Iraq. Both ships were searched during their journeys for materials prohibited under the U.N. embargo against Iraq, U.S. Navy officials said. At the other end of the Persian Gulf, a third Indian ship unloaded food and medicine at the Iraqi port of Umm al-Qasr. The U.N. sanctions committee allowed the 12,972-ton Vishwa Siddhi to deliver the supplies under a provision permitting humanitarian shipments. In Dubai, children arriving aboard the Tipu Sultan clutched teddy bears. Some refugees greeted relatives whom they had been unable to contact since the Iraqi invasion. About 100,000 of the 185,000 Indians in Kuwait and Iraq were believed to remain stranded. ``It's terrible,'' said one Indian, who identified himself only as Rocky, of his journey. ``We hardly drank good water aboard the ship.'' His wife, Gracie, seven months pregnant, shrugged off the discomfort. ``It's nothing compared to the relief we feel coming here to Dubai,'' she said. The first of four Air India jets carrying the ship's refugees to Bombay took off Sunday afternoon, with the others to leave later. Air India said Sunday it would cancel some other regularly scheduled flights during the next two weeks to concentrate on airlifting those fleeing Kuwait. Many refugees expressed both joy and sadness at leaving Kuwait, where some had held well-paid jobs. Now, some face an uncertain future back home, and they left most of their belongings behind. They spoke of sharp hikes in food prices in Kuwait. One mother of two said the price of bread has doubled and is becoming scarce. Unlike the Indian refugees who arrived on another vessel last month, many of whom were exhausted to the point of collapse, the latest evacuees seemed healthy despite the heat and shortage of good water. The Indian vessel Al-Safeer brought out 725 people earlier this month. But the attempt to continue the sealift was held up when Baghdad insisted the vessels bring in food and medicine despite the sanctions. A U.S. Navy official in the Persian Gulf confirmed the boarding of the Akbar and said the Tipu Sultan also had bee searched en route. The official, who asked that his name not be used, said boarding teams found papers in order and no prohibited material aboard.

DOC.HEAD: Senior Governing Party Official Quits Protesting Caste Policy
DOC.TEXT: A founder of the governing party quit Parliament on Sunday to protest Prime Minister V.P. Singh's plan to reserve nearly half of government jobs for low-caste Hindus. The plan has ignited weeks of riots in which at least 50 people have been killed in clashes with police. In addition, nearly a score of upper-caste students have committed suicide, leaving notes blaming Singh. Devi Lal, a founder of the governing Janata Dal party, said he was resigning to protest ``the style, timing and manner'' in which the prime minister had adopted the job quota plan. He released a letter accusing Singh of ``undue haste'' and failing to consult his Cabinet or the parties supporting the 10-month-old minority coalition. ``I cannot support the government which is so insensitive to the cries of dying children and is leading the country to ... fragmentation,'' said the letter. It accused Singh of ``preparing the ground for civil war.'' Devi Lal handed his letter to Singh at a meeting of parliamentarians from the minority National Front coalition. After he left, the meeting gave the prime minister a vote of confidence. Four of Devi Lal's supporters objected to the procedure and walked out. Devi Lal's seat remains vacant until a special election is held. Before Sunday, the Janata Dal controlled 136 seats in the 529-seat lower house of parliament and its coalition partners have three seats. Enmity between Singh and Devi Lal has mounted for months, but Singh's party now appears more openly split than before. Singh fired Devi Lal from his position as deputy prime minister Aug. 1 after weeks of political infighting. Six days later Singh suddenly announced the job policy, in what analysts read as an attempt to upstage the populist Devi Lal just before he held a massive rally to demonstrate his support among the rural poor and underprivileged classes. On Saturday, about 20 of Devi Lal's supporters in the Janata Dal prepared a memorandum condemning Singh's leadership and suggesting that he resign. But Devi Lal's resignation Sunday came as a surprise. Also Sunday, news agencies reported six more students died from self-inflicted injuries, raising to 19 the number of suicides in the past 11 days. The policy reserves 27 percent of civil service positions for people from backward castes, as defined in a 10-year-old government report. Another 22.5 percent already had been set aside for the lowest level of society, the outcastes and the tribespeople. Hindus, who comprise 82 percent of India's 880 million people, are divided into four main castes and thousands of sub-castes which set social standing according to birth. Caste often determines profession, education opportunities and income levels. The government says it promoted the plan to counteract discrimination and win social justice for the historically deprived castes. Upper-caste students say they will suffer reverse discrimination and lose jobs for which they are better qualified. The government employs about 18 million people. Official figures say more than 13 million Indians are unemployed. About 5 million of them are classified as educated.

DOC.HEAD: Ousted Prime Minister Goes Before Tribunal
DOC.TEXT: Ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto went before a special tribunal Sunday and professed her innocence on corruption charges brought by the army-backed caretaker government to try to ban her from politics. Ms. Bhutto was ordered to stand trial before the special one-judge court on charges of misconduct and abuse of power during her 20 months in office. Thousands of slogan-chanting well-wishers waited outside the Sindh High Court building for Ms. Bhutto, who was dressed in a bright-pink tunic and trousers and clutched a prayer written by a supporter. The 37-year-old former prime minister said she did not recognize the jurisdiction of the tribunals. The courts were originally established following a 1977 military coup and resurrected last month by the caretaker government. ``I have come here to show the people the hollowness and maliciousness of the whole process,'' Ms. Bhutto said before entering the courtroom. ``I have come here because I want to make a point - that the former prime minister and the leader of Pakistan's biggest political party is being dragged from court to court,'' she said. ``This is aimed at keeping us from fighting the election.'' About 1,000 people jammed the benches, aisles and window sills to watch the proceeding. Ms. Bhutto sat quietly during the hearing, listening to her lawyers and occasionally scribbling notes. The former prime minister has been ordered to stand trial on similar charges this week before a special tribunal in the eastern city of Lahore, the capital of Punjab Province and a stronghold of her political opponents. She could be disqualified from the Oct. 24 parliamentary elections and banned from politics for seven years if convicted on any charge. Justice Wajihuddin Ahmed promised the proceedings would not hamper the campaign. He adjourned the trial until Oct. 10. The charges allege Ms. Bhutto illegally used an Asia Development Bank loan to hire a foreign consulting firm to oversee a Karachi power project and allowed a British-based firm to export cotton at rates far below the international market rate. The former prime minister has denied any wrongdoing and accused the president and the caretaker government of launching a witch hunt against her, her government and her left-leaning Pakistan People's Party. Ms. Bhutto spent nearly six years in prison, under house arrest or in exile after her father, the late Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, was overthrown by the military in 1977 and hanged two years later. She was elected to Parliament in November 1988, in the first free elections in more than a decade, and became the first woman to lead a modern Moslem nation. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, using his constitutional power, dismissed Ms. Bhutto's government on Aug. 6 and installed a caretaker government made up largely of her opponents. Ishaq Khan accused Ms. Bhutto's government of corruption, incompetence and abuse of power. The caretaker government says it has substantial documentary evidence to back up the charges. But many Pakistanis believe the charges have generated a wave of sympathy for Ms. Bhutto. Most analysts say Ms. Bhutto and her party appear to be gaining strength and could emerge from next month's election as the single largest party. ``I cannot be disqualified because I have not done anything,'' Ms. Bhutto said. ``I am confident that we will be vindicated and with the support of the people will emerge victorious.''

DOC.HEAD: French Foreign Legion Arrive As Britain, Egypt Beef Up
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The main contingent of the French troops joining the U.S.-led multinational force in Saudi Arabia, many of them desert-hardened Foreign Legionnaires, disembarked Sunday at this Red Sea port. About 2,000 men and some 50 vehicles arrived on three ferries. On Monday, two ships carrying fewer than 1,000 men and about 50 AMX-10 armored reconnaissance vehicles with 105mm guns are expected in Yanbu. Their arrival will complete the sealift of France's 4,000-member Rapid Action Force, which will be based in the northeastern desert south of Kuwait. About 1,000 troops arrived Saturday. The arrival of the French force came as more Egyptian troops were expected to reinforce the 11,000 men already based in the desert with an Arab-Islamic force of Saudis, Kuwaitis, Syrians, Moroccans, Pakistanis and Bagladeshis. Britain's 7th Armored Brigade, successors of the famed ``Desert Rats'' of World War II, was embarking from ports in West Germany and Britain to join the swelling multinational force confronting the Iraqis. France has 14 warships in the region and is sending three squadrons of combat jets, for a total commitment of 13,000 men in the largest deployment of French forces overseas since Algeria's war of independence 30 years ago. Convoys pulled out of the sprawling industrial port for the three-day trip across the desert to Hafr al-Batin, the headquarters of the Arab force that forms a defensive screen north of the U.S. forces. Most of the legionnaires have had experience in desert warfare in Chad, where they fought Libyan-backed rebel forces, as well as Djibouti and Ghana, so they should acclimatize quickly to the Saudi climate, Derville said. Derville said the legionnaires include about 30 junior officers and men of Arab origin who had been given the option not to take part in the campaign. But all volunteered. The troops' main concern was chemical weapons. They said nuclear, biological and chemical training was now being emphasized but their previous experience was insufficient. ``You'd put on a mask for two hours and go into a gas chamber and then come out,'' said Cpl. Robin Skillington, 39, a legionnaire from Chatham, Ky. The French Foreign Legion is made up of men from more than 90 countries. The legionnaires will be facing French weapons, including 155mm artillery and fighter jets, sold to Iraq during the 1980-88 Iran-Iraq war. France was Baghdad's main arms supplier after the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Sunny Weather Prevails Over Most of Nation
DOC.TEXT: Clear weather prevailed over most of the nation Sunday, with steady showers confined to some eastern and southern states. There were scattered showers elseswhere. Thunderstorms spread over southern Arkansas and northern Mississippi and there was scattered rain from northern West Virginia to northern Maine. Some rain was reported along the eastern Gulf Coast and in the desert Southwest, but dry weather prevailed over most of the nation. There were sunny skies over much of the western half of the country. The last day of September was a warm one in much of the nation, especially in the West and east from Texas to Florida. McAllen, Texas, reported a low Sunday of 75 degrees and Miami Beach, Fla., had a low of 76. Heavier rainfall totals for the six hour period ending at 2 a.m. EDT Sunday included nearly 2 inches at Vero Beach, Fla., 1.35 inches at Melbourne, Fla., and 1.34 inches at Zanesville, Ohio. The low Sunday for the Lower 48 was 26 degrees at Gunnison, Colo.

DOC.HEAD: Serbs in Croatia Seize Weapons; President Returning Home
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of militant Serbs seized weapons from a police station in ongoing struggles over autonomy for the Serbian minority in the Croatian republic, according to authorities and news reports Sunday. Police sealed off the town hall in Dvor after about 1,000 Serbs seized arms and ammunition from the police Friday night. The clashes there and in two other towns left one policeman seriously injured. At least 27 people were arrested, the reports said. Meanwhile, the armed forces threatened unspecified ``urgent steps'' against the independence-minded republic of Slovenia, whose parliament moved Friday to strip the federal government of control over the republic's defenses. President Borisav Jovic, a Serb who holds the annually rotating chairmanship of Yugoslavia's collective presidency, announced he would cut short his visit to the United Nations in New York ``because of the deterioration of the political and security situation'' at home, the state news agency Tanjug said. The announcement referred indirectly to Slovenia's actions Friday. The Defense Ministry appealed Saturday to the president to take action to keep federal forces intact. Yugoslavians are at odds over the future of the country's fragile, six-republic federation. The republics are fractured along religious, ethnic, economic and political lines. Croatia and Slovenia want the country to be changed into a looser confederation of sovereign states. Serbia seeks to maintain tighter central control, and even to change its border with Croatia to incorporate Serbs living there. The rivalry between Serbs and Croats has escalated sharply since a center-right government ousted the Communists in free elections in Croatia last spring. Serbs make up about 10 percent of the population of the Croatian republic, but are the majority in some towns. Croatia's authorities last month rejected calls for greater autonomy for some Serbian strongholds. Several hundred Serb women and children, said by Tanjug to fear special Croatian police units, spent Saturday night huddled in army barracks in Petrinja, about 25 miles south of Croatia's capital, Zagreb. In Dvor, 25 miles south of Petrinja, special police patrolled th8e town and schools were ordered closed until the police units leave town. Tanjug reported from Zagreb that some roads in the area around Knin, another Croatian town dominated by Serbs, had been blocked off by Serbian militants. Some of the militants were threatening to cut off roads to the coast unless people arrested over the weekend were freed.

DOC.HEAD: Superpowers Begin Drafting Resolutions To Authorize Force Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The United States and the Soviet Union have begun drafting resolutions to authorize the use of military force against Iraq if a worldwide economic squeeze does not force a retreat from Kuwait, U.S. officials said Sunday. Both superpowers would move against Iraq under U.N. auspices, but the Soviets prefer to work under a joint military command while the United States prefers more ``logistical'' leeway, the officials told The Associated Press. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who has repeatedly cautioned Iraq that the military option might be taken, consulted last week with more than a dozen foreign ministers attending the U.N. General Assembly session. They included the British, French, West German, Japanese, Canadian and Italian ministers, who met with Baker over dinner Wednesday night. Iraq's occupation of Kuwait, which is resisting a freeze on trade ordered Aug. 6 by the U.N. Security Council, was the main topic. ``A lot of ideas are kicking around,'' a U.S. official said. ``Everybody is asking what we will do next.'' The official said the drafting at this point was tentative - ``back of the envelope stuff,'' is the way he described it. ``Everybody is looking at options,'' he said. The officials said other delegations also have begun drafting proposed resolutions, all with the view of being ready to act against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to restore Kuwait's national legitimacy. There was no indication when the Council would be asked to take up a call for action. Besides the economic boycott, the Council has approved a military blockade and, last Tuesday, an embargo on air traffic. The officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the Bush administration was inclined to act under Article 42 of the U.N. Charter instead of Article 51, which affirms the right of self-defense. Article 42 authorizes ``action by air, sea or land forces as ... necessary to retain or restore international peace or security.'' The Soviet Union, which is cooperating with the Bush administration against Iraq, is taking a harder line toward Saddam in plotting military action, the officials said. Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze signaled a tough stance Sunday saying ``we are a permanent member of the security Council and we will comply with any decision, with any resolution of the security council.'' Shevardnadze, interviewed on NBC-TV's ``Meet the Press,'' added: ``That would include anything regarding the involvement of the Soviet troops under the flag, under the auspices, of the United Nations.'' In principle, Shevardnadze said, he would like to see the use of force ruled out. But, he said, ``If extreme conditions develop, then any decision must be taken within the framework of the security council.'' Shevardnadze stressed that the U.N. military staff committee must be involved if force is used against Iraq. Within the Bush administration, meanwhile, senior officials are intensifying the threat of force if economic sanctions do not compel Iraq to withdraw from the oil-rich emirate. On Friday, Brent Scowcroft, the president's assistant for national security, said the ``systematic destruction'' of Kuwait under Iraqi occupation is shortening the time that the United States can wait for sanctions to drive out the Iraqi army. President Bush will have a chance on Monday to coordinate strategy with Moscow during an afternoon meeting with Shevardnadze. Baker will then see the Soviet foreign minister on Wednesday, their third meeting in less than a week.

DOC.HEAD: First Public Inquiry Into Pan Am Crash To Check for Security Lapses
DOC.TEXT: Families of victims in the crash of Pan Am Flight 103 say they hope a public inquiry opening Monday, the first in the case, will help determine how the bombing might have been prevented. The inquiry is expected to look at airport security lapses, but it won't seek to assess criminal responsibility for the crash. Families of some of the 270 victims want the investigation to cover security not just at London's Heathrow Airport but also at Frankfurt, West Germany, where the flight originated. The Boeing 747 was bound for New York when it blew apart over the small Scottish town of Lockerbie on Dec. 21, 1988. Eleven of the victims were people on the ground. Investigators say there is not enough evidence to prosecute anyone for the attack, but they have pursued clues pointing to radical Palestinians. The public inquiry, run by a Scottish judge, will be held in Dumfries, 12 miles from Lockerbie. The proceedings, expected to last three months, are being held in a hall converted into a courtroom. The inquiry will take evidence on the plane's airworthiness, air traffic control, the emergency response, the deaths, the destruction of the aircraft, and security arrangements, the Scottish office said. In a key ruling at a preliminary hearing Sept. 20, the judge rejected efforts by the British government and Pan Am to restrict evidence to Britain. The judge, Sheriff Principal John S. Mowat, ruled that evidence from Pan Am baggage handlers at Frankfurt Airport would be admissible if it he thought it relevant. After the preliminary hearing, Jim Swire, who heads a relatives' group called U.K. Families-Flight 103, said he was ``much more optimistic'' about getting a fair hearing on how the bombing could have been prevented. ``We have not wavered from our determination to see British security examined in at least the same detail as U.S. security has been, and we can't imagine why they've waited 21 months even to start,'' said Swire. His 24-year-old daughter, Flora, was killed in the bombing. A U.S. presidential commission, which spent nine months investigating the crash, reported in May that ``the destruction of Flight 103 may well have been preventable.'' The commission cited lapses in security, including failure to physically search luggage transferred from other airlines. It said no effort was made to ensure that all bags were accompanied by passengers. Its report called for notification of passengers when there is a credible bomb threat and said the United States should consider military strikes or covert operations against air terrorists. Swire said the families have much greater confidence in the Scottish judiciary, which is separate from the English judiciary. ``We feel sure it will treat us fairly, and we intend to give it an opportunity to do so,'' Swire said in an interview Friday. The British government has rejected the families' request for an independent investigation, saying all necessary ground would be covered by the continuing police investigation and the public hearing. Scottish investigators have said they are investigating Ahmed Jibril's radical Palestinian group, the Popular Front for the Liberation Of Palestine-General Command, and Mohammad Abu Talb, a member of another radical Palestinian group jailed in Sweden for bombings in northern Europe. Other unidentified individuals and groups are also under investigation. Police say the bomb was hidden inside a radio-cassette recorder in a suitcase that was probably put aboard the flight in Frankfurt. Baggage was transferred from a Boeing 727 to a larger Boeing 747 when the flight stopped at Heathrow.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Death Toll in Uprising Tops 1,000
DOC.TEXT: The Palestinian death toll in the uprising against Israeli occupation climbed above 1,000 Sunday with rioting in a West Bank village and recriminations against Arabs suspected of collaborating with Israel. Police gunfire in the village of Jamain killed one Palestinian and wounded 21 others, four seriously, the army command said. Israel radio described the riot there as ``severe.'' Three Palestinians were slain Sunday on suspicion of collaborating with Israel, according to Palestinian reports. The army said it was checking the reports. An Arab man was injured Sunday while trying to hurl a bomb at a bus stop near the southern Israeli port city of Ashdod, police said, and a masked man tried unsuccessfully to stab a Jew in Jerusalem's walled Old City. The unrest came after roads into Israel were re-opened from the occupied West Bank and the Gaza Strip. The territories had been sealed off for 24 hours for Yom Kippur, the Jewish Day of Atonement. The army said the violence in Jamain, a village of 3,000 just south of Nablus, began after a jeepload of paramilitary border police ``encountered disturbances'' and attempted to disperse the rioters. Arab journalists said Palestinian students at the village's high school hurled stones at the troops. The Israeli patrol fired some 15 tear gas cannisters into the school and, aftering calling reinforcements, raided the building. Parents of the students rushed to the school, trying to stop the troops, and clashed with them inside the compound, Arab reports said. Ahmad Shehadeh, 58, was hit with two bullets in the head and the neck and was dead on arrival at Ittihad hospital in Nablus, hospital officials reported. The alleged collaborators whose deaths were reported Sunday included Adel Abu Baher, 23, whose body was found near the Gaza Strip refugee camp of Khan Yunis. Arab reports said he was stabbed to death by uprising activists. Imad Abu Jubeh, 25, a suspected drug dealer, was stabbed to death in the Gaza village of Beit Lahiya, Arab reporters said. In the Gaza town of Rafah, masked activists killed 53-year-old Hmaidan Kashta, firing several shots at him in the school where he worked as a guard, Arab journalists said. Six suspected collaborators have died in Rafah this month. Arab reporters based in Gaza said all the victims were shot in the same way and attributed the murders to the ``Black Panthers,'' a mysterious group of enforcers operating in the town. Sunday's deaths raised to 1,003 the number of Palestinians killed in the 34-month uprising against Israeli rule over the lands captured in the 1967 Middle East war. According to tallies kept by The Associated Press, 731 Arabs have been killed by Israeli soldiers or civilians in the rebellion, and 272 have been slain by fellow Palestinians, most on suspicion of collaborating with Israel. In the unrest, 52 Israelis and foreigners have been killed by Arabs. Meanwhile, Gaza and parts of the West Bank were paralyzed by a strike called by underground uprising leaders to express sympathy for residents of Gaza's Bureij refugee camp. The camp of 20,000 has been under curfew since an Israeli soldier was killed there Sept. 20. The army has demolished or sealed over 40 shops and homes in Bureij since the killing.

DOC.HEAD: Even In Desert, Bureaucracy Is Long And Slow
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Inside a dusty tent, sheltered from gritty desert winds, a dozen Indian officials toiled Sunday on a bureaucratic assembly line to ready passports for weary refugees. Outside, along rows of olive green army tents painted a reddish yellow by the desert sand, about 13,000 Indian refugees in a transit camp waited, and waited some more. Even in this barren wasteland, the bureaucracy is slow and agonizing. ``We were called out at 3 a.m. and told to assemble with our belongings,'' said George Thomas, a 39-year-old Indian engineer who left Kuwait six days ago and is waiting for his passport to be processed. ``Some buses came, some people left but many were left behind. Now our embassy tells us to go back to our tents and wait for further instructions. ``Maybe it was a misunderstanding between our officials and the Jordanian police,'' allowed Thomas. ``We find the Indian embassy hasn't coordinated all the transfers. They are supposed to call us by the repatriation numbers attached to each passport, but they never follow them.'' Inside one tent, blue-turbaned Indian diplomat G.S. Chhokra, between assignments in Helsinki and Madrid, continued his work. He quickly and steadily processed passports as he talked to two reporters. Chhokra said that so far 81,000 Indian refugees from Iraq and Kuwait had been repatriated from Jordan. He said he hoped 3,400 to 3,500 others would leave for home sometime Sunday. The Indian government believes it can complete the evacuation of all Indians, including those remaining in Iraq and Kuwait, by Oct. 10, he said. ``We are working 12- to 14-hour shifts with no Saturdays or Sundays (off),'' said Chhokra. ``I have never worked so hard.'' But some refugees forced to bide their time and endure the boredom of the desert camp wonder aloud if the diplomats work hard enough. ``Those who have influence go first,'' complained P. Radakrishnan, a 40-year-old construction worker who has waited four days for a flight home to Bombay. ``If you don't have influence you don't go at all. They have not gone yet,'' he said, nodding to the other men in his tent. ``They have no influence.'' Such sentiments led to a brief but violent episode last week when refugees stormed a minibus that they erroneously believed was taking the relatives of an Indian official to the airport. Chhokra, without looking up from his work on the passports, dismissed the complaints as baseless. ``Human nature being what it is, everybody wants to go earlier than the others,'' he said. The desert bureaucracy, like those elsewhere, works invisibly and seemingly mysteriously, at least to the thousands forced to wait in tents and food lines. The red tape compounds the misery of people who already have lost everything. ``We got out of our tents when we heard the police calling on us to get going,'' said one Indian caught up in the confusion over the buses on Sunday. ``As soon as we left our tents the newcomers came in and started grabbing everything,'' said the man who would identify himself only as James. ``Now we must stay and some of the things they took are very dear, such as food, blankets and kerosene stoves,'' he added, more out of frustration than bitterness. ``There is no way we can get those things back.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, South Koreans Establish Diplomatic Ties
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with Shevardnadze saying relations with South Korea should not adversely affect ties to North Korea. Pickup 9th pvs, `The Soviet...'
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union and South Korea established full diplomatic relations Sunday in what was seen as a major victory for the Seoul government and a devastating setback for Communist North Korea. The Soviet Union has been a major ally and arms provider for North Korea. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and his South Korean counterpart, Choi Ho-joong, signed an agreement establishing the ties, issued a joint communique and stood together in a U.N. corridor, smiling and answering questions. ``We have agreed to establish diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and South Korea as of today,'' Choi later told a news conference. He said both sides had agreed to an exchange of high-level visits, possibly by heads of state, but no date was set. He said a Soviet trade and economic delegation will visit Seoul next month to discuss broad economic cooperation. ``We believe that establishing diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and South Korea will aid the cause of stability in Asia and the Pacific region,'' Shevardnadze told reporters. He called South Korea an important factor for peace in the region. Shevardnadze added that improved relations with South Korea would not adversely affect Soviet relations with any other state - an indirect reference to North Korea. There was no immediate comment from North Korean diplomats at the United Nations. The move was widely seen as a diplomatic blow to Pyongyang, which has become increasingly isolated amid the recent trends elsewhere toward democracy and liberalization. South Korea has long been pushing for ties with the Soviet Union, and Moscow has been eager for enhanced trade and economic cooperation to help bolster the sinking Soviet economy. Moscow and Seoul have signed agreements on trade, economic investments, transfer of technology and other cooperation. Bilateral trade was $600 million in 1989 and is expected to reach $1 billion this year. The Soviet decision would leave China as North Korea's most powerful Communist ally. But China, too, has been cautiously improving its relations with South Korea and is interested in South Korean investment and technology. Choi said he hoped the development would spur China to establish full diplomatic ties with Seoul. ``We hope this move will help end relations of confrontation and competition between the North and South,'' he said. Both Koreas currently hold non-voting observer status at the United Nations. Sunday's move was expected to give South Korea more leverage in its bid to join the United Nations as a full member separately from North Korea. The north has opposed separate entry, saying it would only reaffirm the division between the nations. South Korean diplomats have said they would only seek U.N. admission if they are certain that China, a permanent member of the Security Council with veto power, would not oppose them.

DOC.HEAD: Catholic Church Reports Foul Play in Reporters' Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Two journalists whose deaths were reported as traffic fatalities were apparently killed by gunfire, a church-related human rights agency reported Sunday, and it demanded a government investigation. The bodies of the two Salvadoran reporters, Pedro Martinez, 28, and Jorge Euceda, 38, were found in their car Friday on the Pan American Highway, 27 miles east of San Salvador. ``There was definitely a criminal hand in this, but many things remain to be cleared up,'' said Maria Julia Hernandez, director of the Roman Catholic Church's Legal Aid office. Police reports blamed the deaths on a traffic accident. But Hernandez said her office had demanded an autopsy that showed Martinez had bits of ammunition in his left eye and cuts on the sides of his body. ``They shot at the journalists and some bullet fragments lodged in the face, making him lose control of the vehicle he was driving,'' Hernandez said. The blood on the pavement and the absence of it inside the vehicle ``could mean that the journalists were dragged out of the automobile and then beaten to death,'' she added. Hernandez said no there were no suspects. The deaths immediately aroused the suspicions of reporters, who requested the assistance of Legal Aid. The news media and relatives of the victims have called for a complete investigation of the deaths. Martinez was director of the magazine Semana (Week) and correspondent for the prestigious Mexican magazine Proceso. Euceda was a contributor to the Diario Latino, the most liberal Salvadoran daily newspaper, and a professor in the journalism department at the National University of El Salvador.

DOC.HEAD: Hungarians Vote In Local Elections
DOC.TEXT: Hungarians voted in local elections Sunday that mark the final stage in the nation's rapid evolution to a multiparty democracy. It was the fifth election in less than a year for Hungary's estimated 7.8 million registered voters, and a degree of voter burnout was evident. Election officials said only 34.5 percent of the electorate turned out in the capital. More than 40 percent voted in most towns with less than 10,000 people. Earlier elections were for members of Hungary's 394-seat Parliament and other offices. On Sunday, more than 27,000 seats on 3,093 local councils were at stake. All but 163 of the councils serve communities of less than 10,000 inhabitants. The new local governments will be self-governing bodies with jurisdiction over local taxes. Electoral law stipulates at least 40 percent of the electorate must vote in each locale for the vote to be valid. A second ballot is scheduled for Oct. 14 in communities where the quota is not reached. Official results are not expected until Monday. Although 42 parties and many independents were on the various ballots, Sunday's vote was also seen as a test of popularity for the governing Hungarian Democratic Forum and the liberal opposition, the Alliance of Free Democrats, almost six months after national elections. One closely watched contest was in Budapest, where Free Democrats candidate Gabor Demsky, a longtime dissident under the Communists, was challenging a City Hall official from the Forum.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Makes Quick Dash to Washington for Budget Meeting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf pvs, bgng: On Monday, to UPDATE with resolutions being drafted on use of military force against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: President Bush interrupted a diplomatic blitz on the Persian Gulf and raced through a summit on children's problems Sunday to dash back to the White House for the climax of talks on a $500 billion deficit-reduction agreement. The hurried trip scrambled plans for Bush to meet in New York with nine world leaders to bolster international resolve against Iraq for its invasion of Kuwait.
