Bush completed his quick round trip to the White House and back in less than five hours, and quickly stepped into an extended round of diplomatic one-on-ones with visiting foreign leaders. He planned a working dinner with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Sunday night. Bush missed five bilaterals while in Washington. He rescheduled two Sunday evening with Spanish Prime Minister Felipe Gonzalez and Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, and two more on Monday evening with Bangladesh President Hussain Mohammad Ershad and El Salvador President Alfredo Christiani. Before going to Washington, Bush briefly joined more than 70 world leaders at the United Nations for the first World Summit for Children, focusing on problems such as malnutrition and disease which claim the lives of 40,000 infants around the world each day. The president, eager to fly to Washington to announce the budget accord, cut out large chunks of his prepared speech and spoke for only eight minutes. He did not pledge any new money to meet the summit's goals to improve life for poor children but recited U.S. efforts to improve education, eradicate measles and reduce infant mortality and low-weight births. ``All children must be given the chance to lead happy, healthy and productive lives,'' Bush said. He acknowledged that the United States, which ranks 19th among nations in preventing infant mortality, could take lessons from some other countries. ``Programs can best enhance the welfare of children by strengthening the mutual responsibilities of public institutions and individual families,'' the president said. ``We should also look to the private sector as an essential partner.'' He said ``When it comes to improving the welfare of children, empowerment should begin first with their parents.'' In his haste, Bush omitted remarks that less bureaucracy and a free-market system will bring prosperity, which he said is ``the surest antidote to disease and starvation for any society.'' Bush mentioned the Persian Gulf crisis only in passing, saying the world had ``acted decisively in defense of a principle - that small states shall not become souvenirs of conquest.'' On top of meetings Sunday with the presidents of Brazil, Venezuela and Czechoslovakia and dinner with Thatcher, Bush added King Baudoin of Belgium. The presidents of Italy and Yugoslavia were penciled in for Monday afternoon. That left Bush with 10 bilateral meetings set for Monday and 22 during his three days in New York. The only leader scratched from Bush's schedule was NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner. On Monday, Bush will address the U.N. General Assembly. U.S. officials said the United States and the Soviet Union have begun drafting resolutions to authorize the use of military force against Iraq if economic sanctions do not force a retreat from Kuwait. Brent Scowcroft, the president's national security adviser, has suggested that Iraq's destruction of Kuwait was bringing the United States and its allies closer to military action. Bush arrived in New York on Saturday with a plan to consult with more than two-dozen leaders over three days. He talked with six heads of state Saturday in a quick series of meetings lasting no longer than 45 minutes each. Before returning to Washington on Monday, Bush will hold talks with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze.

DOC.HEAD: Four Whites Killed in Black Township; Three More Blacks Die
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with three black deaths; picks up 5th graf pvs, `The four...'; ADDs 1 graf with de Klerk to meet Thatcher; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: The mutilated and burned bodies of four whites were found in a black township that has been the site of several racial confrontations in recent months, police said Sunday. Police said they did not know if the attack was racially motivated and they made no arrests. Also Sunday, African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela called for an urgent meeting this week with the government to discuss the violence in the black townships around Johannesburg that has left about 800 dead since early August. Only two of the victims have been white. Police reported the deaths of three more blacks in two townships near Johannesburg, Tembisa and Sebokeng. The bodies of the four whites - three men and a woman - were found next to a burned-out car in Khutloanong, said Police Maj. Johan Fouche. The townshipis 150 miles southwest of Johannesburg near the towns of Odendaalsrus and Welkom. The four apparently had visited a bar in the township Saturday, police said. The bodies, which were badly mutilated with knives and then set afire, were found Saturday night, Fouche said. Local authorities had threatened to shut off electricity a week ago in Khutloanong because residents were not paying their bills to protest living conditions, an official in Odendaalsrus said. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the power remained on after angry residents burned the homes of black town councilors in Khutloanong. But tensions remain high in the township, the official said. There have been several racial incidents recently in and around the mining town of Welkom. Whites in the area are considered among the most conservative in the country and many are opposed to Presidewnt F.W. de Klerk's reforms. In one incident, hundreds of black miners attacked their white supervisers at a gold mine compound, killing one. Blacks also have carried out random attacks on white motorists driving near black areas. White right-wing groups have set up night patrols, and blacks say they have been harassed by the vigilantes. De Klerk says he wants to end the apartheid system of racial segregation and draw up a new constitution that will allow the 5 million whites and 30 million blacks to share power. De Klerk was to meet Oct. 14 with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Britain, government sources in London said.

DOC.HEAD: New Yorkers Both Welcome and Protest World Summit for Children
With AM-UN-Children
DOC.TEXT: Most New Yorkers took the historic U.N. summit in stride, along with the traffic delays caused by dozens of limousines clogging the city. Some tourists, however, resented the intrusion on their vacations. ``Why did this have to happen on my vacation?'' said Linda Katz of Pittsburgh as a police officer turned her away from a street leading to the United Nations complex. ``I had no idea this was going on.'' Most motorists pulled aside to make way for dignitaries - some accompanied by police escorts - traveling to the United Nations in midtown Manhattan. Limousines were double- and even triple-parked on some streets. Bicyclists and pedestrians navigated past the police lines set up around the United Nations and waited for a glimpse of a visiting leader arriving at the front entrance. Protesters were also on hand Sunday, as they had been all weekend. More than 400 demonstrators, carrying small black coffins bearing the names of slain children, on Sunday protested El Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani's participation at the World Summit for Children. The New York Committee in Solidarity with the People of El Salvador rallied in front of the El Salvadoran U.N. mission at noon before leading a mock funeral procession down Park Avenue near the United Nations. ``We don't think Cristiani has any right to speak,'' said Michele Ascione, 27, one of the committee organizers. ``He's responsible for thousands of atrocities against children in El Salvador.'' There were no arrests at the protest, police said. A smaller group protested against Bangladesh President Hussain Mohammad Ershad. Police said fewer people that expected gathered near the United Nations. ``There doesn't seem to be as much interest as we thought in the summit,'' said Officer Scott Bloch. But Darwin Deleon, 12, who sat on a corner a few blocks from the United Nations, knew all about the summit and applauded it. ``I think it's good they all came here to talk about kids because maybe they'll get something done,'' said Deleon, whose Boy Scout troop helped distribute welcome boxes at the United Nations prior to the summit. ``They ought to do something about the Third World. I saw pictures of children with their bones sticking out.'' Karen Krenzin, who brought her mother, husband and 18-month-old daughter, Jesse, on an afternoon stroll to the United Nations, said the summit would likely only be symbolic. ``It's good that they're meeting but it does seem as if they'll just decide to give more American tax dollars to other countries,'' said Krenzin. ``The problem with other countries is that they have too many children.'' More than 70 kings, presidents and prime ministers forged a multi-billion dollar strategy at the U.N. summit to help children, described by participants as the world's most precious resource. President Bush addressed the world leaders Sunday morning, urging nations around the world to ``live up to our responsibilities'' to save children.

DOC.HEAD: Block Party Turns Into Riot: 17 Injured, 89 Arrested
DOC.TEXT: Police used tear gas to break up a block party that turned into a riot when revelers attacked authorities trying to put out a bonfire. Seventeen people were injured and 89 arrested, officials said. Up to 2,000 people were at the annual bash across the street from the University of Akron when fire and police officials responded to a call at midnight Friday to put out a large bonfire. Some of the revelers - mostly college-aged youths - tried to block their entrance and then threw bottles, rocks and glass at emergency personnel trying to douse the fire, officials said. Officer Brian Reilly said when police asked the crowd to disperse, ``They kept the fire going and continued chanting, `Hell no, we won't go.''' Police used tear gas and firefighters turned their hoses on the crowd to break up the melee. ``We were being pelted with bottles and rocks from all sides. People were throwing things from the porches and second-story windows of the houses. It was a bad situation and we had to end it,'' Lt. Tom Hanley said. Some students charged police used excessive force to break up the disturbance. Police Chief Philip G. Barnes denied the charge. Most of those injured received cuts and bruises. There were no serious injuries, police said. Eighty-nine people were arrested on misdemeanor charges including intoxication and failure to disperse, police said. City officials planned to meet Monday to sort out the incident. ``This is a difficult one,'' Mayor Don Plusquellic said. ``It's becoming more difficult as we get further into it. The judges tell me most were not Akron University students. City service crews cleared Kathryn Place, the site of the melee, on Saturday under police protection. Campus and city police ran beefed-up patrols Saturday night. University officials said the party was not a school-sanctioned event. ``There isn't a mechanism for controlling that (parties) on the part of the university since that is off campus,'' said Kathy Stafford, vice president for institutional advancement. About 5,000 students live in the neighborhoods south and east of the University of Akron. The student housing along Kathryn Place is considered the worst of the off-campus housing, said Roger Ryan, vice president of administrative services.

DOC.HEAD: Fire Has Consumed 11,000 Acres Of Okefenokee Swamp
DOC.TEXT: An inch of rain helped quell a fire that has consumed more than 11,000 acres of the Okefenokee Swamp, but it was not nearly enough to douse the blaze, officials said Sunday. ``That one inch will probably hold it down for a little while,'' said Jim Burkhart, spokesman for the Okefenokee Wildlife Refuge. ``But, it's not going to be enough to keep (the fire) down.'' The fire has burned 11,300 acres since it began with a Sept. 1 lightning strike, Burkhart said. The swamp covers more than 700,000 acres, with 396,000 acres in the refuge and 356,000 acres in a federally designated wilderness. Trenches dug in an effort to contain the blaze were holding up Sunday, Burkhart said, but a crew of 500 firefighters still must contend with ``a big flank of fire out in the swamp itself.'' The fire was burning primarily in the southwest part of the Okefenokee, which currently is drier than it has been at any time since 318,000 acres of swamp and adjacent timberland burned in 1954-55. Average rainfall in the Okefenokee is 53 inches per year. Rainfall is 17.5 inches below normal so far this year and 24 inches for the last two years. Before Saturday's rain, only .08 inch of rain had fallen in September, officials said. All public use of the refuge and the Stephen Foster State Park on its west side was cut off. The Okefenokee Swamp Park, a private attraction on the north edge of the swamp, remained open.

DOC.HEAD: Sister Bea Finds New Calling at Beauty School
DOC.TEXT: After 50 years as a Roman Catholic missionary visiting the sick, teaching religion and training altar boys, Sister Beatrice Lorenz has found a new calling - cosmetology. Sister Bea finished two years of training at the Trend School of Beauty in Riverton last month. Now she plans to cut, wash and style hair at the Our Lady of Victory Missionary Sisters convent in Huntington, Ind. At the convent, Sister Bea's clientele will include retired nuns, the convent's administrators and visitors. Sister Bea said she would continue ``primarily in a life of prayer,'' but believes her new skills fit in nicely with her life's work. ``If people look good they feel good,'' she said. Sister Bea, born in Minneapolis, entered the Indiana mission in 1940 and served in Michigan, Utah, New Mexico, Missouri, Colorado and California before moving to Wyomin in the 1960s. Two years ago, she enrolled in beauty school in Riverton in central Wyoming and earned her cosmetology license last month. ``I wanted the challenge,'' the nun said. ``I feel the future belongs to those who believe in the beauty of their dreams.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Calls For Dialogue, World Leaders Meet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout, UPDATING with possible U.N. military force against Iraq mulled, Saudi king's remarks, Israel to distribute gas masks, other. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos AMM1,4,CO1,5
DOC.TEXT: Saddam Hussein struck a softer note Sunday in the Persian Gulf crisis, urging peaceful dialogue instead of ``threats and warnings.'' U.S. and Soviet officials were reported drafting U.N. resolutions to authorize the use of military force against Iraq if an economic squeeze fails to force Iraq out of Kuwait. Saddam said Sunday he no longer opposed foreign-power involvement in seeking a settlement to the crisis, touched off by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. His message, broadcast on Iraqi TV and radio, came as world leaders meeting at the United Nations moved to shore up diplomatic efforts against his country. U.S. officials told The Associated Press the superpowers would move against Iraq under U.N. auspices if other measures failed, but Moscow wanted a joint military command while Washington preferred more ``logistical'' leeway. Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said Sunday that Soviet forces would participate in any action against Iraq authorized by the United Nations. One of the U.S. officials emphasized that the talks with the Soviets were tentative - ``Everybody is looking at options.'' The officials spoke on condition of anonymity. President Bush will address the General Assembly on Monday. Brent Scowcroft, his national security adviser, said Friday that America is considering asking U.N. authorization for military action.

The Security Council has already approved an economic boycott, a military blockade and an air embargo. Saudi King Fahd urged Saddam to seek a peaceful solution, saying: ``It should not be hard or difficult for President Saddam to overcome the hurdles just as he knocked down those that existed with Iran, the Moslem state.'' Shortly after invading Kuwait, Saddam abandoned territorial claims against Iran that had been a major stumbling block to reaching an Iran-Iraq peace. The neighbors fought a bloody war from 1980-88 before a U.N.-brokered cease-fire halted the fighting. When Iraq massed troops on Saudi borders after invading Kuwait, Fahd asked military forces from the United States and other Western, Islamic and Arab states to defend his country, the world's No. 1 exporter of oil. ``Saudi Arabia does not hesitate to knock on the door of peace,'' Fahd said Saturday. ``It is the best door on which to knock at these times.'' His remarks were distributed Sunday by the official Saudi Press Agency. Thousands of French troops joined the U.S.-led multinational force in the gulf on Sunday, and U.S. and British warships stopped and searched a ship carrying refugees from the region. Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir warned in a speech Sunday in Jerusalem that any Arab ruler who attacks Israel would ``swiftly discover he has made a terrible mistake.'' Iraq has threatened Israel. Military chief Lt. Gen. Dan Shomron said on Israel TV Saturday night that Israel sought to coordinate its moves with America in the crisis, but may have to act independently if Iraq put Israeli citizens in danger. But Saudi Defense Minister Prince Sultan bin Abdel-Aziz said Israel must keep out of gulf crisis, no matter how serious the conflict may become. ``We will not allow Israel . . . to defend us against Iraq or against anybody else,'' he told reporters Sunday. Saddam's speech, read by an announcer, said tensions can be reduced in the gulf ``if dialogue replaces the policy of threats and warnings, if the language of peaceful politics replaces the policy of troop buildups and threats of the use of force.'' He said foreign countries could help in solving the crisis. But he again linked any solution to Israel's withdrawal from the occupied Gaza Strip and West Bank, and the pullout of Syrian forces from Lebanon. Saddam said he wanted to open a dialogue with France to explore the possibility of using President Francois Mitterrand's ideas as basis for a settlement. In a U.N. speech Sept. 24, Mitterrand suggested settling the conflict over Kuwait together with other regional problems that might include the Israeli occupation of Arab territories and the Lebanese civil war. In the gulf Sunday, U.S. and British warships stopped and searched an Indian ship ferrying hundreds of refugees fleeing Kuwait. Another vessel docked at the United Arab Emirates with 705 evacuees aboard, and a U.S. Navy official n the gulf said it also had been searched. The official said boarding teams found no cargo prohibited under the U.N. trade embargo. At the northern end of the gulf, a cargo vessel unloaded food and medicine at Umm al-Qasr, Iraq. The U.N. sanctions committee allowed the shipment under a provision permitting humanitarian supplies. Also Sunday, a Chinese Foreign Ministry statement dismissed as ``totally groundless'' a report by the British newspaper Independent that China agreed to sell Iraq a chemical used to make nuclear weapons, missile fuel and nerve gas. Another Chinese statement expressed concern about a Japanese proposal to send military personnel to the gulf, in what would be the first deployment of Japanese troops overseas since World War II. China retains bitter memories of Japan's invasion in the 1930s. It did not elaborate on what assurances it would like from Japan. The Japanese plan envisons an unarmed Japanese force operating under U.N. command. In Yanbu, Saudi Arabia, about 2,000 French soldiers, most of them Foreign Legionnaires, and 50 vehicles came off three ferries and joined convoys to the northeastern part of the country. Among those arriving was American Martin Meyer, a former U.S. Air Force serviceman who joined the Foreign Legion nearly five years ago. ``We are very ... expendable,'' said Meyer, 28, a former resident of Mexico, Mo. ``We are the front line forces.'' The French soldiers are part of an estimated 200,000-member multinational force, dominated by about 165,000 Americans. The Pentagon estimated last week that about 430,000 Iraqi troops were in Kuwait and southern Iraq. Meanwhile, Jordan threatened to restrict the flow of foreigners fleeing Iraq into Jordan unless it got more international aid. More than 600,000 people poured in after the invasion, officials said. Interior Ministry undersecretary Salameh Hammad told a news conference Jordan had received only $1.7 million of $100 million promised by world institutions. ``I'm afraid I will have to ask the government to adopt appropriate measures to ensure that the number of arrivals does not exceed the number of departures,'' Hammad said. Also on Sunday: -Kuwait's government-in-exile said at its temporary base in Taif, Saudi Arabia, that Iraq's decision to cancel the Kuwaiti dinar was ``null and void'' and that the dinar was ``still the official currency of the state of Kuwait.'' The dinar was worth $3.50 before the invasion. -Palestinian guerrilla leader Nayef Hawatmeh returned to Jordan from talks in Iraq saying war is inevitable as long as Washington refuses to link the Persian Gulf and Palestinian issues. Hawatmeh, secretary-general of the Marxist Democratic Front for Liberation of Palestine, met Saddam in Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: Two U.S. Pilots Killed in Saudi Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf, `They were...' to CLARIFY that earlier plane was F-16
DOC.TEXT: Two U.S. Air Force pilots were killed Sunday when their F-15 fighter plane crashed during an exercise in Saudi Arabia, the U.S. military command said. They were the first Air Force personnel reported killed in Saudi Arabia since the beginning of Operation Desert Shield nearly two months ago. An F-16 crashed earlier but the pilot was not hurt. The aircraft, assigned to the 4th Tactical Fighter Wing, was on what was described as a routine mission in the southern Saudi desert on Sunday morning, officers said. The pilots' names were withheld pending notification of relatives. A board of inquiry was assigned to investigate. The crash brought to five the number of U.S. servicemen killed in Saudi Arabia during operation Desert Shield. Five crewmen were injured in the crash of an Army UH-60 Blackhawk helicopter on Saturday. Officers said one remained in critical condition, three in good condition and one was released. Two soldiers have been killed and one hurt in vehicle accidents, and a sailor was accidentally electrocuted on a ship. A Saudi man was killed in a collision of a taxi and a Marine Force pickup truck.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers Say Country Needs Less Than One-Third Number of Machines
DOC.TEXT: The United States has nearly four times the number of mammography machines it needs, contributing to the high cost of breast cancer detection, federal researchers said. Researchers from the National Institutes of Health and the Food and Drug Administration reported in Monday's Annals of Internal Medicine that the excessive equipment and high cost of the test may hinder increased use of mammography machines, which detect breast cancer. ``Despite an increasing trend in usage that we project, we found that the supply of dedicated mammography machines is outrunning the need,'' said lead author Martin L. Brown of the National Cancer Institute. An editorial accompanying the report warned that the abundant supply may not improve health care. ``The oversupply of mammography units may ultimately lead to a situation in which more care does not mean better care, and it certainly is unlikely to mean more cost-effective care,'' said Dr. Alvin Mushlin of the University of Rochester Medical Center. Researchers estimate that each year, 150,000 American women develop breast cancer and about 44,000 die from the disease. Breast cancer rates could be lowered about 30 percent if women received mammograms as recommended by the National Cancer Institute, according to several earlier studies. Although an estimated 10,000 mammography machines were installed in U.S. medical facilities by 1990, only about 2,600 are really needed, the study said. Brown said the study's estimate was based on accepted recommendations for screening mammograms, nationwide figures on the number of machines and an average cost of about $100 per test. ``Even with some follow-up diagnostic tests, we can't come close to accounting for all those machines,'' Brown said. The high number of machines reduces the number of clients per machine, keeping costs high, he said. Money spent on the excess machines could be better spent on record-keeping and follow-up care, he said. If the cost of the test was lowered from $100 to $50 by using fewer machines, the country could save $763 million a year in health costs, he said. Mushlin said the study indicates clearly that the supply of mammography machines far exceeds the needed number, and predicted that the gap would only increase. The NCI is now conducting a nationwide survey of all facilities with mammography machines to further examine the issues raised by the study, Brown said. Although the study did not analyze the reasons for the rapidly increasing number of mammography machines, Brown speculated that hospitals perceive that the demand for breast cancer screening will continue to grow while the cost of the machines themselves is relatively low. A CDC survey earlier this year found that 64 percent of women 40 and older have had a mammogram, up from 37 percent in 1987.

DOC.HEAD: Owner of Football Team Hints At Shakeup Over Harassment Charges
DOC.TEXT: Eds: SUBS 11th graf, `The Boston...', to FIX title to National Organizaton for Women sted `of'. A version also moving on sports wires as AM-FBN-Kiam-Olson.

New England Patriots owner Victor Kiam on Sunday promised ``mammoth changes'' in the football team's management after a sports reporter said she was sexually harassed by players in the locker room. Kiam said he was misled ``by my own people'' about the seriousness of the incident and again offered his apologies to reporter Lisa Olson while the two appeared on NBC-TV's ``NFL Live.'' Olson said on Sept. 17 several Patriots players made lewd comments while she was conducting post-game interviews in the locker room. Kiam originally brushed aside the comments, saying ``it was a flyspeck in the ocean.'' But on Sunday he said he was calling upon Patriot players to come forward with more information about the exchange. ``There will be mammoth changes'' in the Patriots management, Kiam said, without elaborating. ``I have just met with Lisa. I'm not ready yet to determine what I will do to the fullest extent.'' National Football League commissioner Paul Tagliabue said later Sunday he told Kiam not to make changes until the NFL's investigation of the incident is complete. A Patriots player was fined in connection with the incident. Olson, a reporter for the Boston Herald, said Kiam's apology ``was a start.'' Kiam placed full-page advertisements Sunday in Boston and New York newspapers. ``There's no excuse for what happened in the locker room,'' the ads said. But Kiam also asserted, ``I never called Lisa Olson a (bitch).'' Kiam was reported to have called Olson a ``classic bitch'' in the locker room after a game. Kiam denied he used those words, and the newspaper ads quoted three university officials who say they were next to Kiam and did not hear him use those words. The Boston chapter of the National Organization of Women has condemned both the football team and Kiam and suggested that women boycott products made by Remington, Kiam's Connecticut company which makes electric shavers. Kiam said his apology to Olson last week came ``before any boycott was mentioned.''

DOC.HEAD: India-Pakistan Put Kashmir Talks On Hold
DOC.TEXT: India and Pakistan have temporarily suspended talks seeking to reduce border tension in the troubled Kashmir region, a Pakistani Foreign Ministry official said Sunday. ``Talks are still on, but no date for a further round has been set,'' Foreign Secretary Shaharyar M. Khan said. Pakistan wanted the third round of negotiations to be held before mid-October, but India objected and proposed a session later in the month. Pakistan, however, will hold parliamentary elections Oct. 24 and officials did not want the talks to coincide. Both countries are scheduled to attend a November summit of South Asian nations, so direct talks on Kashmir probably won't be scheduled before December, senior Asian diplomats said. More than 1,200 people have died this year in escalating violence linked to a Moslem insurgency in the Indian province of Jammu-Kashmir. Other parts of the territory are controlled by Pakistan. New Delhi accuses Pakistan of aiding militant forces demanding independence. Pakistan denies the charge, but says it supports the Kashmiris' right to self-determination. About 65 percent of Jammu-Kashmir's 6 million people are Moslem. About three-quarters of India's population is Hindu. The United States and other Western countries have urged the traditionally hostile neighbors to work toward resolving the conflict, which began with the 1947 partition of colonial India into predominantly Moslem Pakistan and the mostly Hindu India. The two countries have twice gone to war over the territory, in 1947-48 and in 1965. The wars have left Kashmir divided into Pakistani and Indian sectors. They fought a third war in 1971 over Bangladesh, then called East Pakistan. Pakistan has lost all three wars.

DOC.HEAD: Agreement Does Not Make Budget Deficit Go Away
An AP News Analysis
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 13th graf pvs, bgng: Just the, with 2 grafs to explain that Gramm-Rudman targets revised and extended
DOC.TEXT: Once again, an 11th-hour budget compromise has delayed fiscal chaos. But the agreement that President Bush insisted on Sunday was not ``smoke and mirrors'' will still leave a gaping budget deficit. For it to work, the agreement's major initial impact must be psychological. It must give financial markets enough confidence that interest rates will begin a downward slide. Even though the plan announced at a hastily summoned Rose Garden ceremony holds out the promise of deeper savings down the road, it will not prevent the fiscal 1991 deficit from setting a new record for red-ink spending. Ironically, even as congressional and White House budget negotiators were putting the finishing touches on the deal to pare the federal deficit by $40 billion in the new fiscal year, budget officials were upping the estimate of the deficit by a similar amount. Just a week ago, budget negotiators were talking about a $250 billion shortfall in the absence of spending cuts and tax increases. Now there is a budget agreement, but even its enactment - by no means certain - would produce a deficit of some $254 billion. That's because on Sunday, Budget Director Richard Darman increased the estimate for the fiscal 1991 deficit to $293.7 billion. That's up from the $100 billion he estimated in January and the $231 billion he estimated in July. He blamed economic performance and the spiraling costs of the savings and loan bailout for the latest upward revision. And that new figure assumes that oil retreats from its current $40-a-barrel to $21-$24; that war doesn't break out in the Middle East; and that the economy doesn't totter into a recession. So the final figures could be even worse. Compare the $253 billion level with the target in the Gramm-Rudman budget balancing law of $64 billion. It would take spending cuts of some $130 billion to get spending in line with that target - not the $40 billion of the agreement or the $100 billion talked about over the past few weeks. Under the budget compromise, the $64 billion figure and all the other Gramm-Rudman targets would be abandoned and new targets established that would give the government five additional years to reach a balanced budget beyond the 1993 deadline called for in the present law. Thus, the balanced budget that President Reagan once promised by 1983 is receding from grasp again. Now, budget negotiators don't envision a budget in balance until near the end of the century. ``The markets are not looking at the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings targets as if that's reality, the ones in current law,'' Darman said. No one really believes ``we're on a path to meet those targets,'' he conceded. ``That's been obvious for months if not more than a year.'' That's not to say the measures contained in the compromise won't amount to a heavy dose of medicine that will be hard for many Americans to swallow. The pact calls for a 12-cent increase in the nine-cent gasoline tax and sharply higher taxes on cigarettes and alcoholic beverages. It would make Medicare coverage more expensive and allows many government programs to rise only with the rate of inflation. For the wealthy and upper middle-class taxpayers, the package would have much same effect as an income tax rate increase by limiting the deductions that can be claimed by those making more than $100,000 annually - either single taxpayers or joint filers. And the measure would impose new taxes on the sale of luxury items, including boats and expensive cars, but not high-end electronic equipment as once contemplated. ``It is not a phony smoke-and-mirrors deficit-cutting program,'' Bush said Sunday, vowing to take the package ``to the American people.'' Just two days ago, he was telling Republican audiences in the Midwest that the case he would take to the American people was the one against Democrats in Congress. Bush made two major concessions in the course of the talks: first agreeing, in July, to back away from his ``no new taxes'' pledge; and then, just within the past few days, abandoning his insistence on a lower capital gains tax rate. Did Bush give up more than he gained? ``I don't think we're going to get into the hot rhetoric of what gain or loss there is in terms of - political terms. There will be a lot of time for that to take place in the days and weeks ahead,'' White House chief of staff John Sununu said Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Congress OKs Short-Term Debt Ceiling Expansion
DOC.TEXT: Congress on Sunday approved President Bush's request for a temporary increase in the national debt. The legislation, approved by voice votes in the House and the Senate, will permit the Treasury to keep borrowing to cover government expenses through the end of the week. The Treasury's current debt limit of $3.195 billion is scheduled to drop back to $3.123 billion at 12:01 a.m. Wednesday. Without more borrowing power, the Treasury could be forced to default on Thursday, according to Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady. The bill sent to the president on Sunday night will keep the Treasury at the higher borrowing level through Friday. Congress is expected to consider another debt extension then. A long-term debt bill is being delayed until completion of the legislation enacting the budget deal between Congress and the president.

DOC.HEAD: Businessman Offers to Pay Mayor's Salary If He'll Quit
DOC.TEXT: A Nashville businessman says he'll pay Mayor Bill Boner's $75,000 annual salary if the mayor - who's received more publicity lately for his love life than his politics - will resign. Businessman Lee Beaman says Boner's romantic entanglements, and the media attention that accompanied them, have distracted the mayor from his work. Boner, 45, is in Hawaii with his fiancee, aspiring country music singer Traci Peel, 34. Boner was still married to and living with his third wife when he announced his engagement to Peel in July. ``It is obvious to all of Nashville that Bill Boner is distracted from his job,'' said Beaman, head of Beaman Automotive Group and an officer of Beaman Bottling Co. ``For the good of the city, Bill Boner should resign so we can elect a mayor in a special election and move our city forward,'' said Beaman, who offered to pay Boner's salary to sweeten the deal. Beaman on Friday said he first made the offer a month ago. Boner was expected to marry Ms. Peel in Hawaii Monday, four days after his divorce became final. The Democratic mayor has a year left in his term and has announced he will not seek re-election. His spokesman, Rick Runyeon, said Boner was ``committed to fulfilling his term of office.''

DOC.HEAD: Brazilian President Laments Past Help To Iraq
DOC.TEXT: NEW YORK (P) - Brazilian President Fernando Collor de Mello told President Bush on Sunday that his country had provided nuclear technology to Iraq in the past and now lamented the action, a senior U.S. official said. Collor described President Saddam Hussein as ``insane'' and said aggression cannot be permitted to succeed, Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson told reporters during a briefing on Bush's meeting with the Brazilian leader. Iraq is known to have relied on a number of foreign sources to try to develop a nuclear capability. The Bush administration believes Iraq has begun production of chemical and biological weapons, but it has not asserted that Baghdad is turning out nuclear arms. Collor described the information Brazil had given to Iraq as ``potentially significant,'' but did not provide further details. ``The president of Brazil lamented the fact that there had been some informal, clandestine relations with Iraq in the past that had involved the trading of some potentially significant information involving nuclear technology.'' according to Aronson. It was not clear whether the trade was sanctioned by the government, although the Brazilian president said he renounced ``all such efforts.'' He also said he supported legislation that would prevent former government officials from trading nuclear secrets after they return to private life. Collor said in one instance a former Army officer involved in Brazil's nuclear program became involved in an Iraqi project. As for Brazil itself, Aronson said, Collor promised the South American country would not launch any kind of nuclear project. To demonstrate his resolve, Collor said he recently visited a secret Army nuclear project and threw a shovel-full of lime down the mine shaft as ``a symbolic closing of this effort.'' Iraq and Brazil are two of some 20 nations believed by American experts either to have the capability of producing nuclear weapons or to have actually begun to turn them out. Bush also met with President Carlos Andres of Venezuela and thanked him for playing a leading role in persuading the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries to increase oil production. The aim is to make up for the boycott of Iraqi and Kuwaiti oil which is being boycotted in an effort to force Saddam Hussein to reverse his invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: British Opposition Opens Conference; Gulf Boosts Thatcher
DOC.TEXT: The Labor Party opened its annual conference Sunday looking like a formidable contender for power, but signs emerged that the Persian Gulf crisis was eroding Labor's lead over the Conservative government in surveys. Three opinion polls published over the weekend indicated Labor's lead down to between five and nine points, compared to about 15 points a month ago and a record 24 percent last March. The weeklong conference in the north England resort of Blackpool was to endorse the socialist party's new, moderate platform, which ditches old tenets of the left from unilateral nuclear disarmament to promises to repeal union-curbing laws. The platform has helped push Labor into its strongest position to regain power since Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher ousted the last Labor government in 1979. The government remains in deep economic trouble. But the polls indicated Mrs. Thatcher benefiting from strong public support for sending warplanes, naval vessels and ground troops to the gulf, and the general perception that she is good in a crisis. ``There is the beginning of a gulf effect, but it is indirect,'' said political analyst Peter Kellner. ``It is having an effect on the standing of the party leaders.'' Kellner was commenting on a National Opinion Poll sounding published Saturday in a London newspaper, the Independent, which indicated Labor had 44 percent support and the Conservatives 39 percent. The poll, like most of those on the weekend, indicated the centrist Social and Liberal Democratic Party had nearly doubled its support to 12 percent following its annual conference two weeks ago. Few of those surveyed cited the gulf as a major influence on how they would vote, but large majorities supported the Thatcher policy in the crisis. Since Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Mrs. Thatcher has identified Britain closely with the U.S. military buildup in the Persian Gulf. For the first time this year, Mrs. Thatcher's personal standing overtook that of Labor Party leader Neil Kinnock in the National Opinion Poll sounding. Kinnock has upset the party's left wing by assiduously supporting the Thatcher policy on the gulf. Party managers were confident of marginalizing the left wing, headed by former Energy Secretary Tony Benn. ``All pressure is on to maintain the unity we have so painfully achieved,'' Bryan Gould, Labor's campaign manager and environment spokesman said. Labor's new 20,000-word policy document reflects how far right Mrs. Thatcher has pushed the British political agenda. The document incorporates many of her union curbs and drops previous promises to renationalize most of the state-owned enterprises she has sold off. Labor leaders say they envisage a top income tax rate of 50 percent - compared to 40 percent now and 83 percent when Labor was last in power. The Tories meet next week. This year's party conferences could be the last before the next general election. Mrs. Thatcher's five-year term ends in mid-1992, but governing parties often call elections a year early.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets, Israel Upgrade Relations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 4 grafs after 4th graf pvs, `The two ministers ...,' to incorporate details of direct air flights from a0581, AM-Israel-Soviets, picking up 5th graf pvs bgng: `The Kremlin...
DOC.TEXT: Israel and the Soviet Union announced Sunday that they are opening consulates in each other's countries after a 23-year break in ties. The decision, announced after a meeting between Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy and his Soviet counterpart, Eduard Shevardnadze, represented a major step in retoring relations that were severed after the 1967 Middle East War. Consular relations are a level below full diplomatic relations. The two ministers also told reporters at the United Nations that they intend to start meeting regularly and that their foreign ministries will be in regular contact. In Jerusalem, a senior Israeli official said direct airline flights between the Soviet Union and Israel will begin within a month. Yossi Ahimeir, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said the Soviets did not provide further details about the arrangement. The Soviet news agency Tass reported Sunday that Levy and Shevardnadze discussed air service, but decided to continue talks later. The national airlines of the two countries, Aeroflot and El Al, signed a direct-flight agreement last year, but Aeroflot then said it needed approval from Soviet leaders before the service could being. The flights could accelerate the exodus of Jews from the Soviet Union to Israel, which is already straining to accommodate more than 100,000 Soviet newcomers who have arrived since last year. The Kremlin broke ties with Israel after the 1967 war, during which Israel seized territory from Moscow's Arab allies. A thaw between the two countries began in 1987, when the Soviets posted a delegation in Tel Aviv that operated through the Finnish Embassy. A year later, Israel established a low-level mission in Moscow operating through the Netherlands Embassy. Relations have improved in part because Moscow wants to play a role in Middle East diplomacy. Asked about word from Israeli officials that Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has authorized direct flights between the Soviet Union and Israel, Shevardnadze said that was a complicated issue to be discussed further. A spokesman for Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir announced in Jerusalem on Saturday that the flights would begin in a month. They were expected to accelerate the emigration of Soviet Jews to Israel. Levy and Shevardnadze met for an hour in the chambers of the U.N. Security Council president, the rotating post occupied by the Soviet Union for the month of September. The two leaders arrived separately, Levy solemn-faced and declining comment. They emerged after the meeting, shaking hands and both smiling. ``We have decided - and I am happy to report this - to establish full consular ties between our two countries,'' Levy told Israel radio, speaking in Hebrew. Shevardnadze told nearly reporters that Israel would be opening a consulate-general, the highest level consulate, in Moscow, and the Soviet Union would open a consulate-general in Tel Aviv. The Soviet leader described Sunday's talks as interesting and businesslike. He said the two countries' contacts and exchanges have been developing in many areas. Arrangements for openings of the new diplomatic missions will be discussed in the next week or 10 days, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Colombians Pray for Kidnapped Journalists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 7 grafs to CLARIFY that total of 7 journalists missing, including 6 seized together on Aug. 30; picks up 8th graf pvs, `Hours after ...
DOC.TEXT: About 30,000 Colombians attended a Mass on Sunday to pray for the safety of seven journalists apparently kidnapped by the Medellin cocaine cartel. The government of President Cesar Gaviria has said it has no evidence indicating who might be holding the journalists. But Colombian news media received calls claiming drug traffickers' responsibility for the abductions from a man identified by security forces as a cartel member. A Sunday column in El Tiempo newspaper voiced the frustration of many Colombians over failure to rescue the journalists. ``It seems prayer is the only resource that can be used to help find them safe and sound,'' it read. Families of the victims, government officials and national celebrities were among those attending the midday Mass at a Bogota plaza. Among the missing journalists was Diana Turbay de Uribe, editor of a Bogota news magazine and daughter of former President Julio Cesar Turbay. She was among a group of six journalists who disappeared Aug. 30 after leaving Bogota to interview leaders of a leftist guerrilla group, the National Liberation Army. The rebels denied they were holding the journalists, and rumors spread they were in the hands of the Medellin cartel. Two kidnappings on Sept. 19 - including another journalist - added to speculation the cartel had resumed its campaign of terror after declaring a cease-fire July 27. Hours after abductors seized Marina Montoya, sister of Colombia's ambassador to Canada, an armed band kidnapped Francisco Santos Calderon, El Tiempo's managing editor, after shooting and killing his chauffeur. A telephone caller told El Tiempo the cartel was holding all eight kidnap victims to try to force the government to grant amnesty to traffickers for past crimes. Gaviria has said the government will not pardon the traffickers' crimes, which include murdering scores of political leaders, judges and journalists. In September, the government offered to hold the trials of surrendering traffickers in Colombia and not extradite them to the United States. Gaviria also decreed reduced prison sentences for drug suspects who cooperate with authorities. A cartel statement rejected the government offer.

DOC.HEAD: Student Takeover at UDC Continues
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 3rd graf, ``Trustees Joseph xxx to CORRECT Joseph Evans to Joseph Webb
DOC.TEXT: The city offered to agree to expand the board of trustees of the University of the District of Columbia to end a student protest that has kept the school closed since last week, university officials said Sunday. Negotiations continued between school officials and students who occupied two buildings, including the university's administrative offices. Trustees Joseph Webb and Alonza Evans said they had reached agreement with the students on 39 of their 44 demands. The students were demanding extensive changes in the public institution, including the resignation of 11 of the 15 trustees. They claim the board has allowed the quality of the school's academic programs to decline. The two trustees said they offered to support a city council bill to expand the board of trustees from 15 to 21 members. There was no word from students on how they greeted that proposal. But Mark Thompson, a leader of the student protest, said the occupation would not end until all demands are met. Trustees of UDC, which enrolls about 12,000 students, cannot be forced to resign. They are nominated by the mayor and confirmed by council members. Two trustees have resigned voluntarily and others won't resign while the protest is going on because ``they're just not going to resign under duress.'' Webb said the protesting students, who number around 300, have made their point. ``I wish they students would stop seeing the board as their enemy because I think the board indeed has been awakened,'' he said. Among the incidents that incited the protest was the financially-strapped university's decision to spend $1.6 million so that it could acquire the controversial feminist artwork ``The Dinner Party.'' That issue had not been resolved Sunday, Webb and Evans said. Trustees have said they would reopen the school Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Summit Closes With Declaration, Calls to End Children's Suffering
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CLARIFY no dollar figure for declaration, world bank pledge, picking up 5th graf pvs bgng: `Many of ...'
DOC.BYLINE: LaserPhoto UN8, LaserColor UN108. ^By VICTORIA GRAHAM
DOC.TEXT: World leaders ended an unprecedented meeting Sunday by pledging huge resources to battle the scourges of childhood poverty, and with harsh words for those who commit atrocities in the name of the young. The 72 kings, presidents and prime ministers concluded the two-day World Summit for Children by adopting a declaration promising to fight the hunger, disease and illiteracy affecting children. The summit, the largest gathering ever of international leaders, was aimed at mobilizing governments to save up to 100 million children from death by disease and malnutrition in the 1990s. The final declaration was signed by Louis Sullivan, U.S. secretary of health and human services. Earlier there had been concern the United States might not endorse the plan because it urges ratification of a pact that opposes the death penalty for those under 18 - a practice in some U.S. states. Officials at the summit estimated that achieving the declaration's goals would cost billions of dollars, but the accord gave no monetary figure, and it relies on the goodwill of nations for contributions. Summit organizers said World Bank president Barber Conable Jr. has pledged $500 million per year in a separate program for health and education for children. More than 1 million children could be saved each year by the additional funds, they said. Many of the world's leaders gave at least brief speeches during the meeting, which also provided a forum for bilateral discussions on a variety of themes, not the least of which was the Persian Gulf crisis. President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia said leaders from Adolf Hitler to Iraqi President Saddam Hussein had committed evil for the supposed benefit of children. ``Thousands of times I have heard people defending their servitude to a hated regime by the argument that they were doing it only for their children,'' Havel told the assembly. ``Immorality was thus committed in the name of children and evil was served for their alleged good.'' ``I saw Hitler waving in a friendly way to the fanatic little girls of Hitlerjugend (Hitler Youth). I saw mass murderer Stalin kissing a child with the red Communist youth organization scarf ... I saw Iraqi President Hussein patting children of his hostages whom, as he now says, he is ready to have shot,'' said Havel. British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher noted the sufferings of children in war-ravaged countries such as Mozambique and Lebanon. ``These are evil things ... evil things done by wicked people,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. ``They bring us hard up against the fundamental nature of human personality and character.'' U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar told the assembly, ``There is no way we can reconcile humanity's remarkable progress with the continuance of the misery that counts children among its victims.'' President Bush said childrens can be saved when adults ``live up to our responsibilities.'' But, he said, ``saving one child is a miracle.'' ``We hold an unprecedent summit for those who will live in and lead a new world, their voices still faint and unheard,'' Bush said. ``We are gathered to speak for the children of the earth ... to defy statistics.'' During the two-day summit, the United Nations estimates 2,800 children worldwide died of whooping cough, 8,000 more from measles, 4,000 from tetanus, 5,500 from malaria, 22,000 from diarrhea and 12,000 from pneumonia - all preventable ailments. Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu, noting that universal education was the foundation for Japan's economic success, advocated extra pay and status for public school teachers around the world. ``National development can take place only when all people have the opportunity to receive an education. There should be no more argument as to which should come first - economic development or education,'' he said. Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez noted the problems of homeless children, child refugees and child laborers in Latin America are ``intolerable consequences'' of the huge foreign debts of many countries in the region. Bush departed from the summit early in order to attend budget negotiations in Washington. He was scheduled to address the U.N. General Assembly on Monday. Summit leaders were escorted to their seats in the emerald-carpeted General Assembly Hall by children in national costume holding miniature flags of their countries. Large portraits of children from every continent adorned the walls. A children's chorus sang of peace. Bush was escorted by Jostin Lebo, 14, of Palisades, N.J., who repairs bicycles for less-fortunate children. U.S. aides called him one of the ``thousand points of light,'' sought by Bush as an example of people helping others. The final draft declaration - the action plan for the summit - commits nations to work toward signing the U.N. Convention on the Rights of the Child, already ratified by more than 40 nations. The U.S. government has not signed the U.N. rights convention. Conservatives take exception to the fact that it does not define a fetus as a child with rights and bans the death penalty for people under 18. The 700-word draft declaration was read to the gathering by children, who then passed it around for signature. Afterward, Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said: ``The real work starts now.'' The declaration resolves the signatories to: -reduce child mortality below age 5 by one-third or to a level of 70 per 1,000 births, whichever is the greater reduction; -cut mortality rates of mothers in childbirth by half; -reduce malnutrition among children under 5 by half; -assure universal access to safe drinking water and septic systems; -provide universal access to basic education, and have at least 80 percen of primary school children finish school; -protect children in dangerous circumstances, especially in armed conflict. A clause was added to the declaration at Kuwait's urging denouncing the suffering of children because of ``aggression, foreign occupation and annexation.'' No specific countries are named in the declaration.

DOC.HEAD: With AM-Bush
U.S. Lifting Travel Restrictions on Czech Diplomats
DOC.TEXT: President Bush informed Czech President Vaclav Havel on Sunday night that he is lifting travel restrictions on Czechoslovakia's diplomats in the United States. The travel restrictions were imposed before the East European country abandoned communism. Bush and Havel conferred in Bush's suite at the Waldorf Astoria Hotel. Both presidents earlier attended the World Summit for Children at the United Nations, and Bush is addressing the U.N. General Assembly on Monday. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater said Bush thanked Havel for his country's ``early support of the U.N. sanctions against Iraq.'' He quoted Bush as saying, ``We understand your sacrifices in supporting the U.N. embargo and we are grateful.'' Havel, a playwright and former prisoner under the communist regime, was elected president last year. He told Bush his country is making considerable progress in reforming its economy. Fitzwater said Bush told Havel the United States' is keenly interested in the success of those reforms. ``We want to see you succeed,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Pulls Boeing 737 with His Hair
LaerPhoto MT2100
DOC.TEXT: A stuntman tied a strap to his long, curly hair on Sunday and used it to pull a Boeing 737-200 aircraft more than 55 feet under a blazing sun at Kuala Lumpur's airport. Urged on by cheering spectators, stuntman R. Letchemanaah, 40, tugged the 28-ton Malaysia Airlines plane and the four tons of fuel it was carrying. A crowd of about 500 watched the feat at the airport, and an estimated 1 million people watched on live television. The national news agency Bernama said it first appeared as if Letchemanaah, dubbed ``Malaysia's mighty man,'' might not be able to move the plane. At one point, his feet slipped on the tarmac. He tightened the end of the strap tied to his hair, again faced the crowd, clenched his teeth and fists, leaned over and began to pull the jetliner slowly forward. Letchemanaah, a laboratory assistant with the Rubber Research Institute and a vegetarian, said he went on a special diet for two weeks to prepare for the feat. He said the stunt was a ``matter of concentration.'' Letchemanaah's stunts mostly involve pulling heavy things: A bus with 27 passengers (100 feet); a 6-ton vehicle (with his teeth). He once had his arm run over by a truck without complaint. Letchemanaah's son, Tiagarajan, 13, said he hopes to emulate his father and has been training to pull a car with his teeth.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Vietnam, China Hope For Normal Ties
DOC.TEXT: Vietnamese and Chinese officials meeting in Beijing last week said they hoped to normalize relations between the two countries, the official Vietnam News Agency has reported. Although Beijing and Hanoi maintain ambassadors in each other's capitals, relations have been cool in the past decade because the two countries support warring sides in Cambodia and other territorial disputes. Hanoi's deputy prime minister, Gen. Vo Nguyen Giap, returned from a highly public visit to China on Friday. His trip, during the Asian Games, was the most senior public contact between China and Vietnam since they fought a border war in 1979. Giap met Chinese Premier Li Peng last Monday and ``the two officials exchanged views on all issues relating to the relations between the two countries and other issues of common concern,'' the Vietnam News Agency reported. ``They also expressed their wish that the traditional friendship between the Vietnamese and the Chinese peoples would be restored soon ... and the friendship and cooperation between the two countries would be normalized,'' it said. Giap was briefed by Chinese officials on China's economic, scientific and technical reforms, the report added. Until 1989, Beijing dismissed all Vietnam's attempts at high-level dialogue. Cambodia is the main divisive issue. Vietnam invaded Cambodia in 1978 and ousted the Khmer Rouge, now a guerrilla army backed by China. China also supports two other guerrilla groups against the Hanoi-installed Cambodian government. Early this month, Vietnam's Communist Party chief Nguyen Van Linh, Prime Minister Do Muoi and former-premier Pham Van Dong paid a secret visit to Beijing, Western diplomats and Thai officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Supporters Endorse Mazowiecki's Candidacy for Polish Presidency
DOC.TEXT: Supporters of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki on Sunday endorsed his presidential candidacy against Solidarity leader Lech Walesa. Unlike Walesa, Mazowiecki has made no formal announcement of his presidential bid. He was in the United States this week for a U.N. meeting on children and talks with President Bush. ``We think that Tadeusz Mazowiecki has been unable to announce his candidacy yet due to procedural reasons,'' said Jan Litynski, a leader of the the Citizens Movement for Democratic Action, known by its Polish acronym ROAD. ``We are convinced that he will decide to run after the election schedule is set.'' President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former Communist Party leader, agreed to curtail the six-year term he began in 1989 by 4{ years, and the presidential election is expected to take place as early as Nov. 25. Walesa nominated Mazowiecki, his former adviser and ally, for prime minister n August 1989. The Solidarity leader is supported by the other major political group in Poland, the Center Alliance. Representatives of about 50 local Christian Democratic clubs announced their support for Walesa's candidacy at a meeting in Warsaw Sunday. The clubs consider themselves right of center. Parliament Deputy Stefan Niesiolowski told a TV newscast support for Walesa is ``the only solution in view of the leftist option still ruling in Poland.'' Walesa had a celebratory weekend, observing his 47th birthday Saturday and marrying off his oldest son, Bogdan, 21, to Agnieszka Drozdowska the same day. He received birthday wishes from fellow worshipers after Sunday Mass at St. Brygida's Church, a few blocks from the shipyard in Gdansk where he led strikes in 1980 and 1988 that ultimately changed the political face of Poland. Referring to his presidential campaighn, Walesa told residents gathered in the churchyard after the service that he hoped ``a lively sea wind will keep coming to Poland from Gdansk as it has for the past 10 years.''

DOC.HEAD: Peter Boyle Hospitalized After Apparent Mild Stroke
DOC.TEXT: Actor Peter Boyle was hospitalized Sunday after apparently suffering a mild stroke, a hospital official said. Boyle, 54, was in fair condition in the intensive care unit at University of Utah Health Sciences Center, said nursing supervisor Charlene Barrett. Boyle, in Utah to work on an unidentified film project, was taken to the hospital after experiencing ``mild weakness and a headache,'' Barrett said. Boyle, best known for his comedic acting, was nomitated for a 1989 emmy as guest actor in the television drama series, ``Midnight Caller.'' His film credits include ``Young Frankenstein,'' ``Taxi Driver,'' ``F.I.S.T.,'' the ``Dream Team,'' and most recently, ``Speed Zone,'' opposite comedian John Candy. He also starred in the short-lived ABC series, ``Joe Bash,'' in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Establish Ties with South Korea, Upgrade Relations with Israel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This wraps up material included in AM-Soviet-Israel a0772, and AM-Soviet-Korea, a0730.
DOC.TEXT: In a major day in Soviet foreign relations, the Kremlin established full diplomatic relations with South Korea on Sunday and announced it was upgrading its relations with Israel after a 23-year rupture. The pact with the Soviets was seen as a major victory for the Seoul government and a devastating setback for Communist North Korea. The Soviet Union has been a major ally and arms provider for North Korea. The decision by the Soviets and Israel to open consulates in each other's country, announced after a meeting between Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze and Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy, represented a major step in restoring relations severed after the 1967 Middle East War. Israel seized territory from Moscow's Arab allies during that conflict. Consular relations are a level below full diplomatic eelations. Soviet diplomats also were busy Sunday working on a draft U.N. resolution to authorize the use of military force against Iraq if previous measures by the world body - including a world economic embargo and an embargo on air traffic -fail to force Iraq to retreat from Kuwait, U.S. officials said. The officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the Soviets and Americans were putting their heads together on the issue and that other delegations also are drafting proposed resolutions - all with the view of being ready to act against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to restore Kuwait's national legitimacy. After Shevardnadze and South Korea's Choi Ho-joong signed an agreement establishing ties, they issued a joint communique and stood together in a U.N. corridor, smiling and answering questions. Choi said both sides agreed to exchange high-level visits and that a Soviet trade and economic delegation will visit Seoul next month to discuss broad economic cooperation. Shevardnadze called South Korea an important factor for peace in the region and said, ``We believe that establishing diplomatic relations between the Soviet Union and South Korea will aid the cause of stability in Asia and the Pacific region.'' South Korea has long pushed for ties with Moscow, and the Soviets are eager for enhanced trade and economic cooperation to help bolster a sinking economy. Sunday's move was expected to give South Korea more leverage in its bid to join the United Nations as a full member separately from North Korea. Shevardnadze and Levy told reporters they intend to start meeting regularly and that the foreign ministries of the Kremlin and the Jewish state will be in regular contact. Shevardnadze said Israel would open a consulate-general - the highest level consulate - in Moscow, and the Soviets would open a consulate-general in Tel Aviv. Yossi Ahimeir, a spokesman for Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, said in Jerusalem that direct airline flights between the Soviet Union and Israel will begin within a month. The Soviet news agency Tass said Levy and Shevardnadze discussed air service, but decided to continue talks later. Such flights could accelerate the exodus of Soviet Jews to Israel, which is already straining to accommodate more than 100,000 Soviet emigres who arrived since last year.

DOC.HEAD: Up To 36 Killed In Kabul Rocket Attack
DOC.TEXT: A barrage of rockets slammed into the Afghan capital of Kabul on Sunday, and 10 people were killed when one of the rockets hit a crowded market, Kabul Radio said. The state-run radio, monitored in Islamabad, said up to 36 people were killed by the rockets, fired by insurgents who have been fighting for more than 12 years to topple Afghanistan's Communist-style government. ``These attacks are against all principles of Islam,'' the broadcast said. Afghanistan's governing Hezb-e-Watan, or Homeland Party, has tried to forge an Islamic image since about about 115,000 Soviet troops completed their withdrawal from the Central Asian nation in February 1989. Soviet soldiers marched into Afghanistan in December 1979 to prop up successive Communist governments and crush the Moslem insurgency. Moscow still sends about $300 million a month in military and humanitarian aid to Kabul. Washington contributes about $300 million annually to the guerrillas, headquartered in Pakistan.

DOC.HEAD: Small Plane Crash Starts Fire; Firefighting Plane Also Crashs
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to UPDATES with two dead in second crash, CORRECTS that firefighting plane has four engines, sted two. Picks up 3rd graf, `The plane...'. ADDS three grafs at end with background on firefighting plane.
DOC.TEXT: A small plane crashed in the Olympic National Forest, killing two people and sparking a fire, and two more people died Sunday when their plane crashed while fighting the blaze. A Lockheed Neptune P-2V firefighting plane crashed Sunday afternoon about five miles from the first crash, said Grays Harbor Sheriff's Deputy Ron Whiteman. The plane was dispatched by the U.S. Forest Service to help fight a fire started when a single-engine Cessna 172 crashed Saturday near Wynoochee Lake Dam. The dam is accessible by land only by logging roads and hunting trails. The wreckage and fire, which consumed about 10 acres, were spotted Sunday morning, said Tom Sayre at the U.S. Forest Service office in Olympia. The twin-engine firefighting plane crashed Sunday afternoon near the first crash site in the south end of the forest, about 60 miles southwest of Seattle, Sayre said. The fire was expected to be controlled quickly, he said. The first plane was reported missing Saturday night after it failed to return to Sanderson Field at Shelton. Killed were pilot David W. Wurscher, 46, of Bremerton and Tom Eller, 62, of Newman Lake, said Brian Holmes of the transportation department. Wurscher, who owned the plane, was training to become a search pilot and Eller was an experienced search-pilot instructor, he said. The four-engine Neptune was owned by Black Hills Aviation of Alamogordo, N.M., said company president Arnold Kolb. Black Hills' planes are contracted by the Forest Service throughout the West, he said. Kolb declined to name the two men on board until their families had been notified. Design of the Lockheed Neptune dates back to late 1940s. It has two piston and two jet engines and was first designed for Navy anti-submarine and patrol duty.

DOC.HEAD: Country Music Guitarist, Promoter Killed in Plane Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RESTORES dropped word `said' in lead; ADDS county name in 2nd graf.
DOC.TEXT: A country music guitarist and his promoter were killed Sunday when their plane crashed two miles short of a runway in heavy fog, authorities said. Murry Kellum, 47, of Antioch, who had the 1963 hit ``Long Tall Texan,'' and promoter Johnny D. Swanner, 55, of Hendersonville died in the early morning crash, said Sumner County sheriff Richard Sutton. Swanner was flying the single-engine plane and may have tried to land in a corn field, said Sutton. There was heavy fog east of the airport in Gallatin, which is about 25 miles northeast of Nashville. Swanner ran Transworld Artists Inc. from his Hendersonville home, said his wife, Rosa Swanner. The men were returning from a concert in Ada, Okla., and had refueled in Memphis, she said. Kellum also co-wrote a hit song for the country group Alabama called ``If You're Gonna Play in Texas (You've Gotta Have a Fiddle in the Band),'' Mrs. Swanner said.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Lebanese Support Aoun against Blockade
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of clapping supporters demonstrated around the Presidential Palace in suburban Baabda Sunday, declaring support for rebel Gen. Michel Aoun against an economic blockade by President Elias Hrawi's army. They chanted ``Long live our general!'' and ``We shall break the siege!'' when Aoun emerged from the bomb-shattered palace, waving V-for-victory. ``Your presence here testifies to the will of the people to stand fast against the government of corruption which is trying to starve us into submission,'' he told the crowd. Aoun accused Hrawi's government of seeking the support of the Syrian army to attack the enclave his 15,000 troops hold in parts of east Beirut and the adjoining mountains in the Christian heartland. ``The government of thieves is trying to build a Berlin Wall between Beirut and our free zone. It is also seeking the support of a foreign army to fight the Lebanese army,'' Aoun said. Beirut newspapers reported Sunday that Hrawi won a pledge of support for such an attack from Syria's President Hafez Assad at a Damascus meeting Saturday. Newspaper reports said Hrawi would order the military thrust to evict Aoun from the Presidential Palace if the present blockade against his 60-square-mile enclave fails to bring the maverick general to heel quickly. Aoun refuses to recognize Hrawi's presidency, calling him a Syrian puppet. Hrawi's 20,000-man army, mostly Moslems under Gen. Emile Lahoud, closed all roads and banned food supplies from entering Aoun's zone last week. Fuel and money transfers have been prohibited since July. Hrawi, Aoun and Lahoud are Maronite Catholics, the sect that dominated power in Lebanon since it gained independence from France in 1943. Hrawi last week signed into law constitutional reforms giving the 55 percent Moslem majority an equal share of power with the Christians in a bid to end the 15-year-old civil war. Aoun rejected the reforms, contending they remain illegal until approved by a nationwide referendum.

DOC.HEAD: When Votes Are Counted, Incumbents OK
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: There is no open season on incumbents in the off-year elections five weeks away despite evidence of political cynicism, signs of voter anger and talk of a backlash against officeholders. When the votes are counted, most of the establishment is likely to be right where it is, with new leases on office. The dissatisfaction that shows in public opinion surveys and in the popularity of limiting elective tenure has been translated into voter uprisings only against a handful of clearly identifiable targets. That showed most clearly in Massachusetts, where the real target wasn't even running. Democratic primary election voters took out their anger at retiring Gov. Michael S. Dukakis by turning to outsiders over candidates with any linked to his administration, which is plagued by an economic slump and was forced to push through a sharp increase in state taxes. Tax increases and budget woes, not incumbency alone, are the common denominator for governors in trouble. That's one of the problems plaguing campaigning Republican governors in places like Rhode Island, Kansas, Maine and Florida. And it was one of the factors in the voluntary retirements of 10 governors who didn't run again. Underscoring a primary election record that shows voters are selective in punishing incumbents, Minnesota Democrats rewarded one, renominating Gov. Rudy Perpich, who once had looked like a loser. He's already served 10 years, longer than any other governor in state history. And in all of Congress, with 435 House seats and 34 in the Senate at stake next month, only one incumbent seeking a new term was turned down for renomination. That sole loser was Rep. Donald Lukens of Ohio, a Republican renounced by his own party after a sex scandal. At this point, the Democrats think they can make significant gains in the competition for governors, with 36 states at stake. There are no signs of major change in the political lineup in Congress, although Republicans still hope to beat the off-year odds and gain a seat or two in the Senate, looking to better position themselves for a bid at control in 1992. In Congress, most of what will happen on Nov. 6 already is ordained. Both parties say there are only a handful of real contests for House seats; Democratic National Chairman Ronald H. Brown guesses the count of competitive districts at 20 of the 435, others put it lower. Four senators seeking re-election, two Republicans and two Democrats, have no major party opponents. There haven't been that many uncontested Senate elections in 34 years. And nine more have only token opposition. Ironically, at the same time, there seems to be growing sentiment in favor of limiting the tenure of officeholders. Oklahoma voters decided by a two-to-one margin to put a 12 year limit on service in their state legislature. Term limits will be on the general election ballot in California and Colorado, the latter measure applying to members of Congress as well as state officeholders. Leaders of an effort to do that nationally with a constitutional amendment claim they are gaining support. That's one way out of a situation in which incumbents usually win even though the voters who re-elect them say they don't like the product. A survey conducted for the Times Mirror Center for the People and the Press reflects the mood. ``Cynicism toward the political system in general is growing as the public in unprecedented numbers associates Republicans with wealth and greed, Democrats with fecklessness and incompetence,'' that survey reported, saying the result is political gridlock. It is gridlock that could be broken by a congressional shakeup in 1992, even if the voters don't force the issue. Congressional redistricting guarantees changes in the House, and campaign finance rules will make retirement a lucrative option for dozens of veteran congressmen. Under the law, they can keep leftover campaign funds for themselves only if they retire by the end of the next Congress, an option worth $100,000 or more for 62 House members. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.
