DOC.HEAD: Third-World Businesses Come Through With Payments - And Interest
DOC.TEXT: While big banks and governments fret over their $1.3 trillion in lending to the Third World, one nonprofit group loaned $23.7 million dollars to Latin Americans last year - and got virtually all of it back, with interest. Seamstresses, fruit vendors, carpenters and thousands of other working poor, who power half of all economic activity in Latin America, are beneficiaries of an innovative loan program developed by Accion International. Working through affiliates in 12 Latin American nations, the Massachusetts-based group provides ``small business'' loans to those so poor they either cannot qualify for bank loans or must resort to loan sharks. ``We are a nonprofit organization dedicated to reducing poverty through the creation of jobs and increasing income,'' said Gabriela Romanow, communications director at Accion International, in a telephone interview. Accion International was founded in 1961 as a privae-sector initiative to stimulate community development in Latin America. A network of local Accion affiliates in Latin capitals screen borrowers and approve loans at market interest rates. More than 40 nonprofit U.S. groups, large banks and private donors finance the loan program, as does the U.S. Agency for International Development. ``We have quite a few corporate donors and we also get money from foundations and individuals as well,'' said Romanow. Accion's affiliates had 45,000 borrowers last year who took out loans averaging $227. Romanow said the default rate was less than 2 percent. The reason? Borrowers put up sewing machines and work tools as collateral. Individuals often apply for loans at community meetings or in small groups, so, ``If you don't pay back, everyone knows,'' Romanow said. The success stories are many, like that of furniture maker Ramon Uceta, who used his loans to escape poverty in Santo Domingo, the Dominican Republic. ``Uceta borrowed $20 from a friend to make lamps out of wicker and he made three and sold them for $8 each,'' Romanow said. ``He heard about Accion's affiliate and went in to ask for a loan for his wicker business. About three years later, after 14 loans, this man who had a tiny shack in a really poor neighborhood, was able to expand to 14 full-time employees.'' She added, ``He obviously has been able to move from his little wooden shack where he had no running water or electricity.'' The loans also worked for Petrona Lopez of La Paz, Bolivia, who would occasionally beg in the city streets but has now been able to open her stand selling the national staple, potatoes. She and four others took out loans totaling $646. ``She now has her own stall in the market instead of selling for other women,'' said Romanow. ``She has been able to buy herself new clothing and is able to periodically to eat chicken, a luxury she wasn't able to previously afford.'' Other borrowers include ``tailors, seamstresses, cobblers, broom makers, carpenters, mechanics, every kind of small-scale business that people actually do because they can't find jobs in the mainstream economy, so they start.'' She noted that studies show such workers comprise 30 percent to 70 percent of the labor force in developing countries.

DOC.HEAD: Budget-Cutting Agreement Would Pinch American Pocketbooks
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Updates throughout; also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's budget deal with Congress would dig deep into American pocketbooks. Medicare payments would rise, taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, liquor and boats would go up. Farmers' subsidies would get cut and government services would shrink. ``It's going to be very painful for a lot of people,'' said Senate GOP leader Bob Dole of Kansas, predicting a tough fight for enough votes to get the agreement past Congress. ``The nay-sayers, the nit-pickers may have a field day.'' There's certainly plenty of unpopular stuff to choose from. -Taxes on gasoline and diesel fuel would more than double. The current nine-cent levy would increase by five cents a gallon on Dec. 1 and another five cents next July 1. In addition, there would be a 2-cent-per-gallon tax on all petroleum products, except home heating oil, beginning Jan. 1. That means the federal motor fuel levy would top out at 21 cents a gallon. -The federal tax on cigarettes, now 16 cents a pack, would rise four cents a pack on Jan. 1 and another four cents in 1993. -Medicare taxes and fees would increase, while benefits go down. Middle-income taxpayers, not just the elderly, would pay for Medicare. Currently, the payroll tax of 1.45 percent stops after a taxpayer's income hits $51,300. The budget deal would keep workers - and employers - paying until a $73,000 income cap. State employees who currently don't pay the Medicare tax or Social Security would be brought into the system. Meanwhile, Medicare patients would pay more of their doctor bills. The annual deductible would double in two years from $75 to $150; coverage for clinical testing would drop from full to 80 percent; and monthly premiums would rise from $28.60 to about $34 next year. By 1995, they would rise to about $54 a month. -Buyers of new cars, boats, jewelry and furs would pay a national sales tax on luxury goods. The fee would be 10 percent on the portion of car purchases above $30,000, boats and yachts above $100,000, and jewelry and furs above $5,000. Boat owners also would be hit with a new Coast Guard fee, a $25 annual decal. And the Army Corps of Engineers would begin charging fees at recreational sites it oversees. -Most individuals or families with in excess of $100,000 in annual income would pay more income taxes, with the government disallowing 3 percent of itemized deductions. But medical expenses or investment interest would not be limited beyond what they already are. -Taxes on beer, wine and other alcoholic beverages would rise although the exact figures remained to be decided. Tax on a six pack of beer would go up 20 cents to 36 cents. Wine would cost about 33 cents more for a regular-size bottle. The three-cent federal tax on wine hasn't changed in nearly 40 years. Hard-liquor taxes would also go up $1.20 per gallon of distilled spirits. While taxpayers would be shelling out more money, government spending would be cut back in many areas. There would be broad cuts in government defense and domestic spending. -Farm support programs would be cut $13 billion over five years. -Providers of Medicare services would be forced to absorb a portion of rising costs equal to roughly $32 billion over the next five years.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Budget Plan Would Boost Taxes, Cut Federal Spending
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 7th graf, ``Arrangements were xxx to update with plans to fly bill to Bush; Inserts grafs 9-12, ``Rep. Newt xxx with additional reaction; inserts graf 15, ``The agreement xxx to include explanation that the deal also changes Gramm-Rudman targets; and subs 23rd graf, ``Cigarette taxes to CORRECT that beer tax going from 16 to 36 cents a six-pack; NOT from 8 cents to 16 cents
DOC.TEXT: President Bush and congressional leaders on Sunday forged a $500-billion, five-year compromise package of tax increases and spending cuts, spurring Congress to quick action on a stopgap spending measure needed to avoid slashes in federal services Monday. The House approved the temporary financing bill just three hours after the budget agreement was described by President Bush in a Rose Garden announcement, and the Senate quickly followed. ``It is balanced, it is fair, and in my view it is what the United States of America needs at this point in its history,'' Bush said in announcing an agreement that concluded budget negotiations that began in May. The package contained $134 billion in new tax revenues, including new taxes on gasoline, cigarettes, alcohol and luxury items. Medicare costs for the elderly and disabled were increased; defense spending was slashed as well. On a 382-41 vote, the House passed what is called a continuing appropriations resolution to keep the government operating at full speed through next Friday while lawmakers weight the proposed budget compromise. The resolution, which then passed the Senate by voice vote, also includes $2 billion in new appropriations for the Desert Shield operations in the Persian Gulf. Arrangements were being made to fly the legislation to Bush in New York Sunday evening, but it was not clear whether he would sign the measure prior to a technical midnight expiration of the existing budget. As a practical matter, however, the exact timing of his signature - which was a certainty - was not significant as long as it occurred within a day or so. House Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., praised the compromise, but agreed with Senate Democratic leader George Mitchell of Maine, who said ``Now comes the hard part,'' in pushing it past special interest groups and through Congress. Rep. Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the No. 2 House Republican and a leader of the party's conservative wing, left the White House before the Rose Garden announcement of the deal, not yet ready to support the package. ``We're still looking at it,'' he told reporters later. ``I'm still thinking.'' At the other end of the political spectrum, Rep. Charles Rangel, D-N.Y., said he would oppose the package because ``it looks like a tax on people who are hurting the most'' and Rep. Nick Joe Rahall, D-W.Va., said, ``I don't think it goes far enough in getting the wealthy to pay their fair share.'' Ron Pollack, executive of Families USA, a non-profit group that advocates on behalf of the elderly poor said the negotiators ``have declared war on our grandparents'' and warned that those who back the plan ``shouldn't expect older Americans to be pacifists on Election Day.'' Edwin Rothschild, head of Citizen Action, a non-profit national consumer organization, complained that the gasoline tax is a regressive measure that will hit poor and middle-income people hardest. ``With gasoline and heating oil and other energy prices going through the roof, it is absolutely the wrong time for Congress and the president to be sticking the cost of the S&L bailout and other crisis on the average citizen,'' said Rothschild. The compromise would shear $40 billion off the deficit expected for the new fiscal year. Without action, the 1991 shortfall was projected to hit $294 billion, $73 billion higher than the previous federal record for red ink and almost triple the shortfall the administration said it anticipated in January. White House budget director Richard Darman attributed the higher deficit projection to the deteriorating economy and growing projections of the costs of rescuing the savings and loan industry. The agreement would waive the current deficit targets of the Gramm-Rudman law, which would have required the new fiscal year's budget gap to not exceed $74 billion. With congressional leaders at his side, Bush said ``I do not welcome'' the tax increases - which he opposed during his 1988 election campaign. But he said they were needed to help the country's economy, and he said he would join in a bipartisan effort to get the package enacted by Oct. 19. ``I will do everything I can to generate support from the American people for this compromise,'' he said. The components of the final budget compromise was a delicate political balance between tax increases Democrats sought and spending cuts Republicans favored. ``We all made compromises in the national interest,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo. Republicans in Congress will be reluctant to accept the tax increases, while many Democrats will look warily at domestic spending reductions, with most programs held to increases matching the inflation rate for the next three years. There also were broad reductions in projected future spending for social, pension and agricultural programs. The toughest cuts would affect the military - $10 billion in the new year and up to $182 billion over five years. Among the tax measures was a gradual boost in gasoline taxes from its current 9 cents per gallon to 21 cents - a 12-cent boost that includes a two-cent per gallon tax applied to all petroleum fuels, except heating oil. Cigarette taxes, now 16 cents a pack, will go up 8 cents more by 1993. The 3-cent-per-bottle wine tax will increase to 24 cents; the 16-cent tax on a six-pack of beer will go to 36 cents; and the $12.50 per gallon tax on hard liquor will grow by $1.20. Luxury items such as fancy cars and jewelry will have a new 10 percent tax. And taxpayers who earn more than $100,000 annually - either as individuals or couples - will have their deductions reduced by 3 percent. But the package has tax breaks too, which Republicans argued were needed to help the economy. Companies that explore for gas and oil, conduct research or do business in depressed urban and rural areas will qualify for tax advantages. The elderly and disabled, who now pay $28.60 per month for Medicare coverage of doctors' expenses, would see that premium increase to about $34.30. The $75 cap on doctors' costs Medicare recipients must pay each year will be boosted to $150. Overall, half the savings in benefit programs - $60 billion - would come from Medicare, split evenly between recipients and providers, such as doctors and hospitals. In addition, upper income taxpayers will pay more to support the Medicare program. The government now takes 1.45 percent from paychecks to finance Medicare up to an annual limit of $51,300. That ceiling will be increased to $73,000, an official said. Farm support programs would be cut $13 billion over five years. Changes in the way payments are made to civil service retirees and postal workers would save $12 billion. Overall, Bush said $134 billion of the savings would come from newtaxes and fees; $182 billion from defense and domestic cuts and $120 billion from reductions in benefit programs like Medicare. The rest would come from reduced debt payments. ``This will be seen as sufficient pain, I think,'' Foley said. Negotiators completed their work early Sunday afternoon after Bush returned briefly from a busy work day at the United Nations in New York. In one of the final battles, Bush abandoned his effort to win a reduction in the capital gains tax rate. In the end, the proposal never made it into the final package - but neither did higher income-tax rates on the wealthy that Democrats had demanded in return. The two sides also agreed to drop another idea that made Democrats and Republicans alike nervous: exacting savings from the nation's 33 million Social Security recipients. Proposals to increase taxes on Social Security benefits or to restrain the growth of those benefits both fell victim to both parties' fears of angry - and well-organized - elderly voters. With no agreement, federal spending would have automatically been slashed by $85 billion Monday, enough to force many of the government's 2.1 million civilian workers to face unpaid days off and the public to deal with curtailed services. The furloughs would have included air traffic controllers, workers who process Social Security checks and FBI agents.
